To be more precise and clear, the title of the book should be "why the modern theory of evolution is true." Changing the title doesn't make a difference to us the believers of the theory (I'll call the theory Darwinism for short), because we usually accept it as a bundle package. But after reading the book, I realize the theory makes multi-level propositions. "Evolution happened" is only one of them. Coyne mentions this structure of Darwinism repeatedly, but I think he could make the book stronger by laying it out at the very beginning. In my own words, the theory of evolution proposes the following hierarchy of propositions:1. Evolutionary change (change in inheritable traits of a population through generations) happened. Not only on the micro level (change of traits within a species) but also the macro level (the transformation of one species into another)2. Natural selection explains most of the microevolutionary change, e.g., the change in beak size of birds.3. Natural selection explains most of the macroevolutionary change, e.g., the origin of birds.4. Natural selection builds complex features in nonhuman species, such as the eyes and the brain.5. Natural selection builds complex features of humans, such as language and consciousness.  Some creationists refuse all propositions above. Some admit (1) but refuse to explain it by natural selection. Others accept natural selection only to a certain level. All of them share one common belief: natural selection cannot make us human to be what we are. As a response, Coyne provides ample evidence to support Darwinism. The evidence includes the following: • Species can be classified and grouped in a tree-like way• Discovery of transitional fossils at predicted locations with the expected age.• Features that only make sense by natural selection: vestiges / atavism / dead DNA / Embryo palimpsest / bad design• Distributions of species across the globe, such as how different species fill similar roles in different areas, how certain species lack on volcanic islands but not on continental islands, and the radiations of endemic species on volcanic islands.• Speed and capacity of adaption caused by artificial selection• Speed and capacity of adaption caused by natural selection in labs and fields• Math simulations that exhibit evolutionary paths to complex features under natural selection. An important lesson I learned from Coyne's enumeration of the evidence above, is to treat the following two things differently: 1) the general evolutionary theory, and 2) individual evolutionary explanations of traits and behaviors. Darwin provides us a beautiful theory. It is so simple, yet so powerful. But beauty does not equal truth. Darwinism is generally correct because scientists have accumulated a huge amount of supporting evidence. An individual evolutionary explanation, however, must bear its own burden of proof. We should not blindly believe in a single evolutionary explanation because there are often multiple competing evolutionary explanations of a trait or behavior. Many of them are inevitable "just-so stories." Moreover, natural selection is not the only chisel used by nature the sculptor. Features can be generated by other mechanisms, such as genetic drift and sexual selection. I found the hypothesis explaining the existence of human appendix especially interesting: it is possible that natural selection simply can't shrink the appendix anymore, because before it disappears from shrinking, a smaller appendix gives rise to a higher risk of being blocked.  This lesson also applies to economics, another discipline that is guided by a core theory — the rational choice theory. Again, the core theory might be generally correct, but this does not mean it is correct in every context, far from it.  Coyne also reminds me that most evolutionary explanations of complex human features, no matter how elaborate, are untested and probably untestable. This is unfortunate, because the evolution of such features, especially the evolution of consciousness, seems to be the most intriguing question of all. But to quote Darwin, we should not "positively assert that this or that problem will never be solved by science." Instead, we should keep searching for testable theories in the future.  Stray observation:- The book solved a big puzzle I had in high school biology class: why human embryos look so weird and go through phases of development that make no sense.- Darwin did not explain the origin of species in his same-titled book (he would explain it in later books and papers). A better title for The Origin of Species, would have been The Origin of Adaptations.

tl;dr Evolution is true. The big picture is indisputably clear. What remains is to probe the finer details of the mechanics and processes underlying it. If Coyne's primary goal in writing this book was to convince Creationists that evolution is true, it remains unfulfilled. The people he's trying to convince are precisely the kind whom no amount of evidence supporting evolution can convince. This book lacks the only thing that can convince Creationists and proponents of Intelligent Design - passages from their holy book of choice, or even better, a direct quote from their god of choice, stating evolution is true. Kidding aside, the sad truth is that it is nigh impossible to fight dogma and deeply entrenched beliefs with logic and evidence. That doesn't mean we shouldn't try. This book is the result of one such attempt and it is a brilliant one at that. Kudos to Coyne for fighting the good fight. Unless you're the kind of person who relies exclusively on made-up stories from stale, antiquated texts for moral guidance and laws of the natural world, you probably already know evolution is true, or rather, that it is the best explanation we have so far for the origin of life on this planet; and I'm fairly sure you will find this book insightful and enjoyable. The book is full of interesting facts and observations that unequivocally prove that evolution is a scientific fact. Topics that are covered include discovery of fossils, particularly of intermediates; speciation and biogeography; vestigial traits and organs that along with emryology provide a window into the past; genetic drift as an alternative (although minor) engine of evolution besides Darwinian natural selection; the powers of sexual selection; and lastly, the origin of of our own species along with a brief but useful discussion on the dicey issue of race. Along with a historical overview, Coyne also details recent evidence (last three decades) supporting evolution and advances made in paleontology, molecular and evolutionary biology, and a few other fields, which I found very helpful. At one time or another, I'm sure most of us have wondered, "Now that the pressures of natural selection are largely absent in most human societies, are we still evolving? If so, in what ways?" I found the beginnings of an answer to this in the penultimate chapter.The crisp, clear, and no-nonsense writing style makes digesting this information-rich book painless. Coyne has also provided handy notes clarifying certain ideas, pointing out opposing viewpoints, and lisiting resources for those interested in exploring a topic further. Several of the books he has mentioned have found their way into my to to-read list.This is a cogent synthesis of facts about evolution and of coherent arguments in its favor. Not only does it satiate your curiosity and expand your mind but it also arms you with knowledge for those uncomfortable engagements with staunch Creationsists. Highly recommended!

The title of this book bluntly states its purpose, which is to refute, head on, the claims advanced by creationists and supporters of intelligent design that evolution by natural selection cannot possibly explain how life takes the many forms that it does. Biologist Jerry Coyne convincingly addresses every conceivable argument that could be made against evolution, using numerous examples to explain how life as it exists today must have arisen through evolution. To this end, he covers evidence from:- Fossils and biogeography.- Vestigial organs (eg, our appendix). - Vestigial genes. We have around 2,000 that no longer work because evolution rendered them unnecessary. An example is our gene for the final step in the biosynthesis of vitamin C which became non-functional after we started to consume this essential substance in our diet.- Atavisms (eg, our coccyx). - Embryonic development, where the early embryos of most vertebrates bear a striking resemblance to one another. The human embryo, for example, starts looking like that of a jawless fish, before becoming reptilian, and then mammalian. - Bad design, such as the asymmetric structure of flat, side-swimming fish, such as Dover sole, or the convoluted route taken in mammals by the recurrent laryngeal nerve (which covers about 15 feet in the giraffe, to join two points just one foot apart).As Coyne points out, no supreme being would have created these oddities and imperfections unless it was that being’s intention to deceive us into believing they were the outcome of evolution, which seems extremely implausible. This is not a textbook on evolution, so its purpose is not to teach the underlying principles. The reader needs to look elsewhere for detailed explanations of genetics, genomes, DNA, inheritance, population growth, genetic drift, etc, but this is the ideal book for anyone who is open-mindedly sitting on the fence, unsure as to whether or not life arose through evolution, creation or intelligent design. Coyne’s arguments are very compelling although, as he admits, “evolution raises such profound questions of purpose, morality, and meaning that [some people] just can’t accept it no matter how much evidence they see”. He illustrates this point by referring to a talk on evolution he gave in Chicago to a group of businessmen. Afterwards, he was approached by one of the delegates who said, “I found your evidence for evolution very convincing—but I still don’t believe it”.

Considering the plethora of books about evolution out there, is it really necessary to publish yet another one? What can another book about evolution have to offer that previous books have not provided? This new book not only presents the latest information about evolution to come to light, but it also responds to the most recent attacks made upon this field of scientific knowledge. The book, 
Why Evolution is True
 (NYC: Viking; 2009) by Jerry Coyne, is the most up-to-date and one of the most clearly written books about evolution that is currently available — and that’s saying a lot since most books about evolution are excellent.This beautifully written and fascinating book delves into the answers to several questions; How has (and is) evolution tested scientifically? What predictions do scientists make based on the Theory of Evolution? Have these predictions been supported by the experimental evidence? This book is Coyne’s detailed presentation of the most impressive and modern discoveries of fossil, animal and plant data that have been published in a variety of scientific fields that impinge upon and contribute to The Theory of Evolution.Take the field of biogeography, for example. Biogeographers have long known that there are two types of islands: oceanic islands, which arose from the seafloor and have never been connected to a large land mass and continental islands, which have become isolated from a large land mass sometime during their history due to rising sea levels or fracturing continental plates. Biogeographers have documented time and again that these two island types can be easily distinguished because all oceanic islands lack native mammals, amphibians and freshwater fish — animals that are present on continental islands. This is not due to any defects associated with continental life since humans have introduced continental species such as rats, goats, pigs and other domestic animals onto oceanic islands throughout history, demonstrating that continental species are quite adept at island life. Additionally, species found on oceanic islands are often very similar to each other — radiations from a few ancestral species — while those on continental islands are not.“Why would a creator happen to leave amphibians, mammals, fish, and reptiles off oceanic islands, but not continental ones?” wonders Coyne. “Why did a creator produce radiations of similar species on oceanic islands, but not continental ones? And why were the species on oceanic islands created to resemble those from the nearest mainland?”The fossil record is consistent with evolutionary biology, too. When paleontologists look for particular transitional forms, they are found in the fossil record precisely where they should occur if evolution occurred. For example, the earliest birds appear after dinosaurs but before modern birds, as we see illustrated on the front dust jacket cover of the book.Primate fossils follow this same pattern. Coyne discusses a series of fossils that are intermediate between chimp and humans, where the older fossils are more ape-like while progressively younger fossils are those that possess more characters associated with humans. Creationists react to this by claiming that all of the great ape fossils are either humans or apes with no discernible intermediates, and that they are separated by “a large and unbridgeable gap.” But interestingly, when tested, creationists can’t agree among themselves as to exactly which fossils are “human” and which are “ape”. “Nothing shows the intermediacy of these fossils better than the inability of creationists to classify them consistently,” concludes Coyne.Developmental biologists have identified atavisms that betray close evolutionary relationships, too. Atavisms are dormant ancestral features that are sporadically expressed during embryonic development and sometimes after birth, too. This is likely due to the activation of genes from an organism’s evolutionary ancestors that remain normally unexpressed. For example, humans possess the genes for making tails, but these genes are usually deactivated. But not always: page 63 has a photograph of a human infant with a 3–4 inch atavistic tail!Speaking of genes, geneticists have also made some interesting discoveries, such as dead genes. Dead genes are those genes whose inactive sequences are found in the chromosomes of particular groups of organisms. “Virtually all species harbor dead genes,” Coyne notes, “many of them still active in its relatives.”Dead genes are even found in the human genome. One example is the human inability to manufacture our own vitamin C — despite the fact that the necessary genes exist in our genome. A close look at the sequences reveals that just one gene has a mutation in it, and this is exactly the same mutation shared between all other primates, while guinea pigs, which also cannot make vitamin C, have a completely different mutation.“Why would a creator put a pathway for making vitamin C in all these species, and then inactivate it?” Coyne asks. “Why would the same inactivating mutation be present in all primates, and a different one in guinea pigs?”Even though Coyne’s initial motivation to write this book stemmed from his annoyance with those who claim that intelligent design is science, he doesn’t attack religion. Instead, as demonstrated in some of the passages I’ve quoted here, he does what scientists do best: he makes predictions. In this case, he makes predictions that naturally arise from evolutionary theory as well as from creationism and “intelligent design” and details how actual scientific data conflict with religious beliefs.Coyne also includes an interesting section in the last chapter of the book where he explores the fear that evolution inspires in many religious people. He points out that religious opposition to evolution is not due to a lack of scientific evidence, for there is plenty of that, but it stems mainly from fears that the moral fabric of society will fall apart if people accept the fact that humans descended from ape-like ancestors. But that said, Coyne goes on to recognize that ethics are not the result of religious belief at all. Further, he is not deterred from using scientific findings to examine humans in the light of our evolutionary ancestry and postulating that this realization could mean a great deal for our future evolution.Most of us do need meaning, purpose, and moral guidance in our lives. How do we find them if we accept that evolution is the real story of our origin? That question is outside of the domain of science. But evolution can sill shed some light on whether our morality is constrained by our genetics. If our bodies are the product of evolution, what about our behavior? Do we carry the psychological baggage of our millions of years on the African savanna? If so, how far can we overcome it? [p. 225]I highly recommend this book to everyone who is seeking a clearly written and level-headed review of the most recent and relevant scientific findings and for how they support modern evolutionary theory.NOTE: Originally published at scienceblogs.com on 21 May 2009.

Jerry Coyne is perhaps best known as a bit of a firebrand, publicly antireligious and antagonistic to creation mythologies. (I once attended a lecture of his where he suggested that the world would be a better place if there was zero religion in it). He is also a successful biologist, and it is easy to conflate these two passions, allowing the atheistic rhetoric to muddy the scientific message. In "Why Evolution is True", both passions are alive but thankfully the jabs against creationism are few and incidental -- this is a book about science. It's not that the jabs aren't warranted (they are), they just seem so conspicuously out of place in what is otherwise a clear and concerted presentation of the facts of evolution. Lucid illustrations of Darwinian evolution are interrupted to point out that creationism or intelligent design simply cannot explain this or that fact or phenomenon. It's like going from 6th gear down to 1st, and the presentation stands strongly on its own merits without giving airtime to these scientifically unfounded speculations. The book would be better without them. That said, Coyne's work fills an important niche in the galaxy of pop-sci evolution books; while many focus on how evolution works and marvel in the amazing natural variety so obtained, "Why Evolution is True" is a book about the evidence for evolution -- the critical observations and facts that support the theory of evolution through natural selection. Coyne presents four pillars of evidence: the fossil record, embryology and vestiges, biogeography, and speciation. Each adds a different piece to the puzzle, and some are mutually supportive. For example, we learn that fossilization is a rare, essentially contingent event that preserves only a vanishingly small subset of all species ever to have existed. Despite this most imperfect collection of snapshots, biologists have had remarkable success tracing near complete lines of evolution of certain species. Take the whale: beginning with a raccoon-sized, land-dwelling mammal called the indohus, scientists have pieced together a striking chronological and structural succession of fossilized species connecting this early progenitor with the modern whale, meandering through a parade of odd-looking, freakish transitional forms. The fossils record a discrete representation of a more or less continuous process, as the pelvis of the indohus slowly shrinks as the hind legs disappear, though not completely: the pelvis, though diminished to barely a nub, remains in the modern-day whale as a useless leftover from its days as a land-dwelling animal. Monstrously telling, one in five hundred whales is born with a rear leg attached to this pelvis: a true atavism that gives scientists a chance to peer behind the curtain.Vestigial pelvises and other outmoded remnants pepper many other species -- understanding their relevance in the context of the progenitor species provides an additional powerful source of evidence for evolution. Defunct wings on ostriches, though since commandeered for the relatively modern need of balance and steering, are another good example. Moles and other subterranean animals living in darkness apparently have no eyes, at least until you push back the fur in a certain place on their heads: hidden beneath this covering, one discovers sightless eyes that are stowaways from an earlier time when the mole's ancestors took in the sun as surface dwellers. Not all vestiges are permanent: as embryos develop, they exhibit a succession of ephemeral vestiges, a nod to their hidden ancestry. The study of embryology is rich in evolutionary gems, and Coyne reveals a truly marvelous fact -- that embryos develop through several stages in which they express different characteristics of their progenitor species, a sequence of developmental stages equivalent to the sequence of speciation shaped by evolution! "A lizard begins development resembling an embryonic fish, then somewhat later an embryonic amphibian, and finally an embryonic reptile. Mammals go through the same sequence, but add on the final stage of an embryonic mammal." (p. 77) But not all of these features are truly ephemeral: the left recurrent laryngeal nerve in humans is two feet longer than it needs to be, taking a circuitous lap from the neck down around the aorta before attaching back up at the larynx. The reason? The human larynx forms essentially from what later becomes a gill in fish. The gill runs more or less parallel to its nerve and blood supply, but as it begins to form the larynx in humans, the blood and nerve supplies get tangled and the nerve must stretch to reach the larynx.Biogeography -- the geographic distribution of species -- is given its own chapter and contributes a few remarkably decisive pieces of evidence to Coyne's cache. In particular, the conspicuous difference in flora and fauna between two types of islands: oceanic, those that are born from undersea volcanoes, and continental, those that separated from larger land masses. Oceanic islands lack amphibians and fresh-water fish. They have a paucity of mammals and large trees. These islands that arise in the middle of the ocean are remote and isolated from only the most tenacious and prolific forms of life: insects that hitch rides on migratory birds, or plant seeds buoyant and robust enough to survive a trans-oceanic voyage. The lack of trees, whose seeds are too heavy to complete this journey, leave for small plants to establish their hegemony: absent competition for resources and sunlight, sunflowers grow into towering behemoths not seen elsewhere on the globe. Meanwhile, continental islands boast unique species, but ones imminently traceable to forebears on the mother continent. Sexual selection is given good amount of air time, but I'll spare you the details here (that are easily as provocative and decisive as the others). Coyne finishes with an overview of speciation, and importantly, with our tale -- the story of the descent of man. This narrative is broken in many places, there are gaps and mysteries, false starts and lineages that meander into nothingness. But within this incomplete constellation of fossil, genetic, and geographic evidence, a path emerges, admittedly approximate, but glorious nonetheless. A certain ancestor named Australopithecus afarensis begins to walk 4 million years ago. We know this partly from fossil evidence: the hips and femurs are structured to support upright mobility; but we also know this because of two sets of footprints preserved in the ash of a volcanic eruption. One set of prints larger -- the male, one smaller -- the female. The right foot of the female leaves a deeper depression than the left -- perhaps she is holding something -- maybe a child? This image of a primeval hominid family, still wild and without language, abstract intelligence, or culture, is nonetheless deeply human. It provides such great perspective on where we came from and how we got here. This is why we study evolution.

This book should be retitled "Why Natural Selection is True". Coyne gives compelling and fascinating proofs for why and how various types of selection work on species to produce new expressed traits. I almost didn't make it to the interesting stuff though, because the first few chapters basically bashed the reader into submission to authority - "everyone who's anything believes in evolution; it's a fact!" Once I got past that, he actually talked about science and how selection works. But no one's really claiming that NS doesn't happen. He does little to show how the unexpressed traits arise in DNA in the first place. There's a little bit about mutation and genetic drift, but he hardly explains how mutation can produce complex DNA without destroying it first. And for someone who debates creationists, he certainly doesn't understand their arguments - many of his arguments against special creation claim that the patterns of variety on different types of islands proves that nature, and not supernature, put those species there. But creationists don't claim that God populated the whole earth with animals all at one time! (garden of Eden, Noah's Flood.) It's little more than a statement that evolutionary biology shouldn't necessarily make us bad. Perhaps he felt compelled to throw that in there, but it's incomplete, and I'd be embarrassed to leave myself so open to criticism.

Jerry Coyne wrote a book with a straightforward title, but that doesn't mean his task was simple. Evolution is not a single science, but rather a theory that involves many sciences. Thus, to make a well-rounded, accessible, current case for evolution, Coyne had to assemble, synthesize, and distill a massive amount of data spanning many scientific domains. On the whole, he was quite successful. Three features of this book stand out as particularly praiseworthy. First is the sheer number and recent date of examples. Much of the debate over evolution on both sides can get detached from continuing scientific progress, stuck at some point in the past. However, the 1990s and the 21st century have already been rich with advances, including perhaps the most compelling evidence for evolution. I think that Coyne could have been even better here by reducing references to Darwin. It is remarkable the extant to which he envisioned the development of evolutionary theory and it is natural to pay respects, but constantly invoking him can obscure where science currently stands. The second is Coyne's focus on evolution's success in prediction. For decades scientists have been assuming that the broad outlines of evolutionary theory are true and predicting future discoveries based on gaps. A striking case is the find of Tiktaalik roseae. University of Chicago researcher Neil Shubin wanted to find a species that would clearly mark the transition from fish to vertebrate. Such a species should occupy a location in the strata dated at 360 to 390 million years. Based on the overall picture of evolutionary descent, it would also occur in freshwater. Shubin selected the most likely spot and after five years of careful excavation, found the remarkable Tiktaalik roseae. It is not only the find itself, but also the way in which the find was discovered that lends confirmation to evolutionary theory as a whole. Biogeography, the study of the locations of animals, is a field constantly experiencing predictive success. When predictions drawn from data in several fields are commonly and precisely confirmed, that's scientific proof. The third is Coyne's handling of creationism. In general, he doesn't. There are a few snarky comments, of which I disapprove, but he is definitely more restrained than most of the voices on either side of the debate. He addresses specific creationist concerns only when they arise naturally in the course of explanation, usually when elements of evolutionary theory itself have been routinely misunderstood. I think refusing to go in for a point-by-point refutation of creationism is a wise choice. Simply providing the positive outlines of evolutionary theory is enough to give readers some perspective when engaging in more detail later. Doing more would have ruined the plan of his book. I was also generally pleased with the last chapter of the book, "Evolution Redux." I would not say it was philosophically sophisticated, but Coyne refused to promote evolution to a philosophy or ultimate theory. He clearly acknowledged that there are limits to science. This distinguishes Coyne from the brash and often embarrassing voices of popular evolutionary writing.The book also contains a glossary and an annotated list of suggestions for further reading. I highly recommend this book. It got off to a bit of a slow start, but gradually improved until it was quite impressive. I have read better books on individual topics, but none that tie so many fields together like this one.

Before reading:I'm really looking forward to this book. When I got it I just figured that I'd read it because it was readily available and because it is by duty as a scientist to read this kind of stuff. However, I've been teaching a lot of evolution lately and I just can't help but be stimulated by such an outstandingly well-supported scientific theory (I say theory here only as a scientist would mean theory - with great weight). So much of the physical life on Earth makes sense only in the context of evolution. Besides, I picked up, at the same time, some book called The Darwin Myth, and while I plan to read that one as well, I just couldn't stomach dragging myself through it first. After I've pleased my imagination (hopefully) and filled myself with gratitude with this book then I'll move on to the nether-readings.After reading:Fantastic book. The only thing I didn't like about this book was that the author framed some of his arguments against creation of universe/earth/life by God. This fault is misguided and unfortunate. The reason the author did this is that this book (as the title of the book suggests) responds to and debunks some of the silliness of creationism/intelligent design. Since creationism/intelligent design are not scientific theories but are fear-induced religiously-based reactions to evolution, the arguments in this book were sometimes pitted against creation by God. It's unfortunate that this was the case since science tells us nothing about God's role in life or even the existence of God. Science is simply a method to learn about the world around us. Science offers us many tools we can use to learn, but science can't help us when the tools aren't capable of measuring the subject. Science never tries to learn about God. This is not because no scientists care about God (many scientists are devout believers), but it is because there have never been any testable hypotheses that the scientific method could be applied to in order to support any claim to the existence or the absence of a God. Since science isn't capable of answering questions about deity, it's pointless, imprudent, and misguided to say that any scientific theory suggests that God does or doesn't exist. Could creation of life on earth happen by speciation and by the evolution of species? Absolutely. Could God have created earth (and the universe) through a singularity knowing that earth would result and that this earth would have the necessary components to allow for life to develop, even in his image? Absolutely. Is this A LOT to get your head around? Absolutely. It is worth your time to get your head around it though. Remember that ignorance breeds fear, and fear (Yes, summon Yoda now, I have) leads to ridiculous apologetics like creationism and intelligent design. Never allow a lack of knowledge to direct your thoughts, especially when a lack of knowledge is so easily cured.

Somewhat contrary to my expectations, WEIT turned out to be considerably better than Dawkins' The Greatest Show on Earth. It still has some very real problems, though, starting with his sloppy use of words (particularly evident early on), which will allow a determined skeptic to take legitimate issue with the book.Fortunately, it picks up when it moves away from the squishy introductory bits into real data, and the rest of the book is pretty solid.He glosses over real (and very interesting) controversies regarding origin and continued popularity of sexual reproduction, though that's somewhat understandable, as a real discussion of the issue would fill (and indeed has filled) several books of its own (my favorite being Matt Ridley's The Red Queen). His discussion of human origins disappointingly doesn't mention neoteny once, but does touch on the aquatic ape crap; and also overstates differences between humans and other apes, for no legitimate reason that I can see.There's also a subchapter on human race, for which braced myself. Fortunately, Coyne doesn't seem to buy into the Gouldian bullshit that race is entirely a social construct of negligible genetic significance that is so popular among American academics (though he does inexplicably refer to The Mismeasure of Man as "superb", which is a stretch even if you agree with Gould; and Coyne is clearly a disciple of Gould's in some other respects, as is clear from his attitude towards sociobiology in the last chapter), but he does tip-toe around some obvious conclusions.He mentions that the notion of races (slash subspecies slash ecotypes) among non-human animals is uncontroversial, but then goes out of his way to stress that races in humans aren't unambiguously demarcated, as if that's ever different in other animals. He spends some time discussing very real genetic differences between human races (sickle-cell anemia, Tay-Sachs disease, lactose intolerance, apart from the obvious), and the incredible speed at which sexual selection in particular can work, but then strangely concludes (based on "informed speculation") that the human races are probably too young for there to be significant differences between them.I don't know if this is genuine confusion of the mind on his part or intellectual hypocrisy brought on by an editor, but I wish American (mainly) authors would stop fucking doing it.Anyway, apart from that, it's a good book, and one which (unlike Dawkins', really) clearly and systematically lays out a lot of the evidence for evolution; or at least such evidence as is easily accessible to a lay audience. Sometimes he's a bit too careful, sometimes he's a bit too vague and technically inaccurate, but on the whole, it's definitely worth reading.

"…understanding evolution should surely deepen and enrich our appreciation of the living world and our place in it."  I really, really like that. This is a fantastic primer on evolution for someone like me that was never really taught it in school. It really makes me reflect on the idea of a literal reading of Genesis. {Is natural selection so hard to swallow when you believe that differences in people have been made in just the few thousand years since Noah?}And is the piecing together of the fossil record any more problematic than the piecing together of the canon we call the Bible? One of the things that strikes me so strongly is the evidence against reading Genesis 1 as literal. To me none of this argues against a Creator, (though I see how some might argue that it makes a creator unnecessary), but as I look around me, Thomas Payne's argument still holds - that God is evident in creation. This goes back to the quote I use at the beginning of this review. But when you look at the facts and the evidence, the idea that God created everything less than 10,000 years ago, there's no way the earth could exist in this current state. Unless, of course, you suggest that God has intervened continuously in the makeup of the natural world, without proof or evidence to back it up. Without even having anything in the inspired scriptures to concur with your claims. The fossil record, vestiges, poor design, biogeography, the variety of species. Why do people ignore the evidence - even the evidence of the scriptures themselves and of church history - to try and "prove" that Genesis 1 is literal. I didn't intend to make this review an argument against fundamentalism, but really, that's what this book is about. The reason behind why evolution makes sense versus a literal young earth creation story. The reason why Kyle Butt and his ilk are so successful at debates is because of their use of snark, sarcasm, and poor logic - which just shows they are better entertainers and know how to play to an audience. Kind of like Rush Limbaugh. They're so good at it, that the people whose prejudice they are reinforcing don't realize - or don't care - how unintelligent they really are, or how the come across as utter assholes. And natural selection - when understood - is extremely fascinating. It's difficult to wrap your mind around sometimes. But it is an amazing idea. Overall, this is an excellent and interesting text - especially if your knowledge of evolution is limited.

Belief comes first and then rationalization of those beliefs, according to Michael Shermer. Maybe that is why 72% of Americans believe in angels, 60% in the devil and only 45% in Darwin's theory of evolution. That there is abundant evidence for the latter makes no difference at all to what people believe and this is the main reason I gave this rather dull book four stars: it is important. It does state many truths on where this world's creatures, including us, came from - and why. This book could as well have been called "Why ID is wrong". The arguments against creationism are strewed all through the book and since I don't need to be convinced, it is sometimes irritating. I have learned a lot more about the mindset for creationism than I have learned new things about evolution. I spent 2/3 of the book wondering why creationists dispute evolution so vehemently. It never struck me, ever, while growing up, that Darwin would be any threat to God. That evolution offers another explanation for "creation", so what. It does not make life or nature any less miraculous nor did I see how it would diminish God in any way. Until I got to the bit about humans - then it dawned on me. OH. Human beings are not the pinnacle of creation. Ooops. I can see how that would irk a lot of people. Evolution is a scientific theory, which means it has been tested over and over again and there is no evidence to disprove it. It is not a religion. To say you believe in evolution is like believing in gravity: it makes no sense as the evidence is all around us. People believe in atoms, electrons, black holes and billions of galaxies - not to speak of all the things people believe in for which there is not a scrap of evidence - it shouldn't be such a stretch to believe that over eons, life evolves. However, as it seems to be that for many, Jerry Coyne has written "why evolution is true". Not that I actually believe he could convince anyone, as evidence is not an issue. There is plenty of evidence in the book, but if you prefer to believe in something else, of course you will continue to do so regardless. The people who sit down and make hard decisions based on evidence are few and far between. I tip my hat to Mr. Coyne for trying and for writing such a clear and lucid book.

The title of this book could just as easily have been -- "Why Intelligent Design is False". I do appreciate the author's patience with all those who are still questioning some of the basic assumptions of Darwinianism, but for once it would be refreshing to see a biologist actually acknowledge some of their own assumptions. Certainly I "believe" (his word) that much in this field of study is "true", but at the same time I am quite aware of the underlying biases in any human pursuit of knowledge and understanding. I just wish that scientists were as forthcoming as I in admitting to them.This writer goes to some lengths to show that evolution has lead to many dead ends and imperfect adaptations, thus "proving" there is no "divine creator", whom he (the author) presumes would have only created "whole, perfect beings". Here is where he displays his ignorance of the tenets of monotheism, at least. I am not here advocating for the biblical point of view -- only stating that this author displays a common ignorance endemic in the scientific community concerning what is actually written in the Bible, as well as what it is that many people of faith actually "believe". One question never answered by Darwinists is the issue of where modern birds came from, since they (evolutionists) insist they are descended from dinosaurs, and the dinos all went extinct 65 million years ago. The basic thesis of this book is that all life on earth has evolved from one organism over the past 3.5 billion years, so the assumption, I suppose, is that the "dino-bird" somehow escaped to live and evolve another day.I began my study of these two worldviews (evolution vs. creationism) in 1968. I have ended up some 40 years later as an empirical metaphysicist -- or, if you prefer -- a metaphysical empiricist. That is, I greatly value the merits of a scientific worldview while simultaneously maintaining the ability to accept less sense-based explanations for certain phenomena -- all without much cognitive dissonance, I might add. I regret that during my lifetime there have developed these two schisms, apparently unwilling or unable to speak coherently to one another.

If you are a rational person who does not believe 99% of scientists are engaged in a big shadowy atheist conspiracy, you probably accept evolution as a scientific fact. Because of the overwhelming consensus in the scientific community, it is perfectly reasonable to hold this belief without having a deep understanding of the supporting evidence. Nobody has time to become well-versed in everything, and so we frequently defer to expert opinions on all manner of subjects. But if you do want to have a solid understanding of the evidence for evolution and common descent, and understand why creationist arguments are a bunch of bullshit, read this book. You don't need a scientific background. If you finish this book and still have doubts about evolution, you are delusional.Coyne, who is an evolutionary biologist at the University of Chicago, clearly lays out the multiple lines of evidence for evolution from various scientific fields, including paleontology, comparative anatomy, genetics, embryology/developmental biology, and biogeography. He also gives lucid explanations of the various mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, sexual selection, genetic drift. And there is a great chapter on speciation (the formation of new and distinct species). Along the way, he debunks common creationist objections to evolution.In no other aspect of life do people require nearly as much evidence as there is for evolution to accept something as factual. That is because many people do not like the implications of being closely related to chimpanzees and ultimately related even to dung beetles and E. coli. That's right, you have a distant cousin that habitually rolls balls of shit uphill, and another one that literally eats shit and periodically fucks up lettuce supplies for a living. Talk about the black sheep of the family! People instead want to believe that they are special little creations objectively on a higher plane of existence than all other living creatures. Sorry bud, you're just a talking ape! If you were born a few million years ago you'd be fit for a zoo exhibit.

I have to start by saying that when I bought this book at my university bookstore for my Human Evolution and Paleoanthropolgy class, the clerk who checked me out mentioned how he hoped I proved the book wrong. I find this incredibly ironic because of what this book is all about. Coyne does not set out to prove creationism wrong, but to prove that evolution is true. And in my opinion, he does very well. When I first started this book I thought Coyne came off a little too aggressively. But by the end of chapter one I was feeling fine again. Maybe his intro was meant to weed out those who would only be angered by the rest of his book; I’m not entirely sure. But the book was very factual and scientific. There was no attacks against creationism, just data that pointed out the flaws in the argument. This is fairly basic information, so I definitely recommend it to anyone who is curious about the debate between evolution and creationism and doesn’t have a huge base of evolutionary knowledge already. For me, it was all mostly a review from past classes and books, but the information was organized in a easy to follow way. And while I had heard all of these concepts before, there were some that I now have a better understanding of. And there were a lot of little factoids about this and that species that I’ve never heard of. I had a lot of fun reading this book. The writing is straightforward and clear. There are perhaps other books out there that are more factual and less pervasive, but I went into this reading with the understanding that this book is more about the debates surrounding the validity of evolution than specifically evolution. I think for readers without a clear understanding of evolution, the book does a great job at informing readers about the topic. I do recommend it.

Like most high school students in the early ‘80s, I was taught the theory of evolution and natural selection in the classroom. But up until recently, I still found it difficult to comprehend how the sophisticated human could have evolved from ancestral monkeys. Mr. Coyne’s Why Evolution is True not only explains evolution from a 21st-century perspective that far surpasses my high school textbooks, he answered many questions about the evolutionary process that—until I read Coyne’s book—had left me wondering. One example: Why do fish, dolphin, and dog embryos look similar to the human embryo? Because, according to Coyne, we’re looking at it backwards: the dog, dolphin, and human embryo look like the embryonic fish—not the other way around. Coyne explains that the developing fetus for each species begins with its original ancestral structure and proceeds through its own evolutionary process. The developing human embryo, for example, develops a yolk, which is later shed; it grow a tail, which is later absorbed; it grows a coat of hair, which is later shed. In other words, evolution is an imperfect, jerryrigged process: in order to get to its current form, it first has to build from its previous ancestral forms. Coyne also explains how evolution produces such drastic changes across species; artificial evolution (such as dog breeding); the seemingly counter-evolutionary mating behaviors of male and female animals; and the genetic heritage of humans and apes based on recent DNA sequencing. Largely written in response to recent controversies over teaching Intelligent Design in the classroom, Coyne’s Why Evolution is True does not disappoint. –Russ (Reference)

A good overview of the evidence for evolution. It's well written and logically set out--though this is what you should expect from a science book. There were good answers given to questions I hadn't even thought about. For example, the fact that the human transitional fossils may represent branches in the Tree and not necessarily specimens of the direct line for homosapiens. I'm always wanting more detail when questions pertaining to genetics comes up, but the lack of depth is understandable given the complexity of the topic. I appreciated the bit on speciation--an important aspect of evolutionary theory that I'd previously under-emphasized. Coyne more or less sticks to science and avoids venturing off into philosophical or religious tangents. The last chapter dealt more with the sociological and psychological implications of evolution and shied away from tackling heavy religious questions. Though I think Coyne's (most probably atheistic) beliefs about religions and God shines through here and there throughout. I feel like Coyne avoids the difficult questions, related to human consciousness for eg., raised in support of the idea that humans are unique among the animal kingdom. This may be so because there's limited space in a small book. I don't know how much I trust Coyne's assessment of ID and creationism. His comments regarding creationists views seem shallow and lacking of substance. Overall a very good book covering the evidence from all the various fields of science for evolution.

This book is amazing. (Or the general 'mind-blown' state I have experienced reading it has been amazing). I cannot believe that I am just beginning to study this topic in depth. I thought a general understanding of natural selection was sufficient, but I have been missing out! I am blown away by what I did not know about evolution and the truly amazing, indisputable evidence of the history of our world and evolution of our bodies. I have been misled by the use of the term THEORY of Evolution, not understanding that the word THEORY has a very different meaning within the world of research than is typically assigned to it in a general vocabulary. The discoveries being made in the field of evolutionary science are awe-inspiring and not at all some 'best guess given limited knowledge'. If you too have been allowed to believe that, please read this book and be amazed. I have a doctorate degree as a health professional, and yet evolution has never been mentioned at any point in my education, let alone a detailed study of the research supporting it - why?! Why is the study of evolution not a required high school and/or college course considered as important as anatomy, physiology and biology? This stuff is an essential precursor and/or companion to the study of anatomy, physiology and biology! This is need-to-know stuff for anyone, not just those who take particular interest in science.

This is a great book if you want a basic understanding of the issues and data behind evolution. He goes into some detail, but not enough to bog you down - like Dawkins can tend towards. He resolved a lot of questions I had, and left me feeling quite deceived or misled at least by the opposition. Some of that might have been intentional, but I think most of it was from a basic misunderstanding of the facts. Things I learned:There are missing link fossils. Fossils are always found in the correct strata for the time period. Creationists could debunk the whole "Theory" by finding one out of place, which they have yet to do. We have seen evolution/natural selection in the lab and in nature. "God's amazing design" isn't so amazing if you start to look at the details and vestigial traits. DNA has allowed us to trace geneological trees and progression of evolution. We are 98.5% similar to chimps. There is no evidence the Biblical Flood ever happened, and plenty that it couldn't have. Distribution of species is one drop in the bucket. Nature is even more incredible than I thought, and now I'm asking more questions and appreciating things in a new way. There is a lot more of course, that's just a few off the top of my head. The scientific evidence is overwhelming, really. Really good read, I look forward to learning more.

This book was recommended to me by my biology professor who happens to be an animal biologist and a population geneticist. I'll try to lay what I learned from this book in the form of points. Jerry Coyne is an accomplished evolutionist. - If you think Darwin was intelligent, he was probably more intelligent than you think he was. - Evolutionary theory doesn't say that species MUST evolve; it's conditioned. It doesn't state that "all" species must evolve. It doesn't predict the speed of the process, either. - Intelligent Design promoters have to explain extinction, and the emergence of new species that resemble (to some extent) the extinct ones. - Most fossils we have of marine organisms because the process of fossilization requires a watery environment. - Fun fact: the length of a day increases by about two seconds every 100,000 years. - We can detect evolution, but sometimes it's hard to uncover what caused it. - J. B. S. Haldane was asked, "What observation could disprove evolution?" He replied, "Fossil rabbits in the Precambrian!" (Which is a powerful funny statement given that rabbits as mammals hadn't showed up yet at that time as predicted by the theory of evolution. - Our control and manipulation of nature, also advances in medicine, have slowed down our biological evolution. They have replaced nature in determining survival of the fittest.

While this books does make a fairly concise case for evolution, and also contains quite a few interesting factoids, I've read better introductory texts on the subject. Not having the book on hand, I can't pinpoint specific passages, but there were a few points while I was reading this book that I found myself thinking "Yes, that's true, but this statement could be misconstrued or misinterpreted. I'm aware of the counter arguments and why they're wrong, but only because I already have a working knowledge of evolutionary theory; someone not as experienced might not understand what has just been said." Coyne makes good points, all of which are accurate, but he fails to either anticipate and deal with counter arguments or, at times, to clarify ambiguous or potentially confusing points. As such, this isn't the best book if you're looking for an introduction to the topic; for that I would highly recommend The Greatest Show on Earth by Richard Dawkins, which is well-written, comprehensive and (unlike many of Dawkin's other works) geared specifically for the lay public. If, however, you already have a good grasp of evolutionary theory, Why Evolution is True does a good job of fleshing out several details, making it a good supplementary read.

One of the biggest hurdles I've recently had to clear is proving to myself that evolution was a fact. Note that I didn't say, "Believing in evolution," as if it were another doctrine or tenet of a faith. Rather, I needed hard proof that it happened and is still happening.This book helped immensely. When you read it, you see how much information that "intelligent design" proponents have to hide in order for their belief to continue to appear plausible. You also see how beautiful and how simple the process of evolution really is. We truly are all connected on this planet: A giant web of animals, bacterium, insects, plants and other secrets that we don't know yet.We are indeed very lucky that we understand our place in this hierarchy, but that shouldn't confer upon us any special feeling of privilege. Rather, it means that because we understand how life works, and how it grows and changes over time, it's our responsibility to be a responsible member of the family here on Earth. We're here for such a short time, and each of us can either do the greatest good or the greatest harm. The choice is up to us individually.

The Pope recently made a statement regarding the church's acceptance of biology. The church recognizes that evolution is a fact and that the Theory of Evolution is a good explanation of that fact. To be fair, the Catholic church has accepted this bit of science for a few decades now. The statement may be 154 years late, but it is nice to know the church hasn't reverted.Anyway, it was a good time to pull this book off my shelf and give it a read. Some of my favorite tidbits: 1 in 500 whales are born with back legs, the platypus has no stomach, human embryos develop three kidneys (the first two resembling fish and reptile kidneys are discarded during the first months of development), and bananas are sterile hybrids.During the reading of this, I kept getting deja vu, but I was certain I hadn't read it before. The answer to this riddle came when I looked over the references and suggested reading. Turns out I've read many of the sources Mr. Coyne is pulling from.The information in this book is fairly basic and logically presented.

Coyne gives a brief introduction to the modern understanding of evolution, followed by separate chapters outlining the various kinds of evidence for evolution, including the evidence of transitional forms, evolution in action in bacteria and in isolated species, etc. He also takes pains to point out the various ways in which evolution is a testable scientific theory, by listing a number of the predictions made by evolutionary theory, any one of which, if falsified, would force modifications to the general theory.Along the way he casually demolishes the various 'gap' claims made by creationists. Sadly, no such demolition is ever likely to have even the slightest effect on creationists, stuck as they are with their religious/mythological understanding of the world.Nonetheless, this is the best book I've read on evolution. I would recommend it to anyone who wants a deeper and better understanding of the theoretical structure of evolutionary theory and its evidence.

We got this book when both my mom and I signed up for a Cousera course on evolution. I didn't manage to finish the course, but I'm glad we got this book.I didn't study evolution in school because it was taught in the 2nd year of high school biology, which I didn't take because I chose humanities division. I remember my friends talking about having to study evolution only to have it refuted a chapter or two later.The book gives a lot of examples of evolution, often with pictures or graphs, and is very convincing. It leaves no doubt that evolution is true, obviously given the book's title.I don't think there's any contradiction between evolution and religion. Evolution to me doesn't mean we weren't created. But I guess the problem for some people with accepting it goes back to how they interpret religious texts. Is everything to be taken literally or not? That's probably always going to be debatable.

A good introduction to the subject, and probably more accessible to the layperson that some of Dawkins' titles. One of this book's strengths is that Coyne has clearly made the effort to engage with and understand the objections levelled at Darwinism by its creationist/ID opponents. If you're a religious believer who is yet to be convinced, don't be put off by the somewhat dogmatic sounding title - the most important word in it is the very first one: WHY. This is an excellent book of argument and evidence rather than dogma. If you're already on board with the 'theory' but feel like you could do with brushing up on the subject, you should get a lot out of it too. With only one book to his name, Coyne has proven himself to be among the very best science communicators, and I hope he will continue to write more.

If you do not accept that Darwinian evolution is the driving force behind the diversification of life on Earth then you just have not read the right books; so put that Bible down and read this one. If you are not familiar with the theory of evolution then you will not be swamped in a flood of jargon when you read this book; but if you are not a newcomer to the theory, then equally this book should not bore you.I think that the theory of evolution is amazing in its simplicity and is really an example of beauty that is so obviously apparent in the world around us.This is not a book to read instead of Darwin’s “On the Origin of Species” but makes a superb compliment to it. The other books that you should then read are Neil Shubin’s “Your Inner Fish” and anything by Richard Dawkins but especially “The Blind Watchmaker

Overall, a solid book that was accessible and readable. At this point, I kind of feel like there has been enough evidence that proves evolution that it is impossible to argue against it. Coyne does a good job of aggregating a lot of this evidence in a concise way. I kept wondering who the audience for this book is supposed to be. Any hardcore creationist will dismiss the book outright, without ever picking it up. And there are times where Coyne seems to be yelling at anyone who doesn't agree with him (he uses a lot of exclamation points). I'm not sure that's how you win over doubters, if that's his goal. I think, more than anything, the book is good at showing a lot of good examples, explaining them in layman's terms, and "arms" the reader with good talking points for future discussions about evolution.

I'd say everyone needs to read this and stop being idiots -- but go look at the counter-books (every popular argument book gets these really terrible 'fleas' that use a pun of their name to identify themselves) and then bang your head on the wall. It's not that there is any good argument against evolution. because if there were it wouldn't exist, it's that people are fucking stupid. Teenagers just looking to get an intro to evolution because your teacher didn't teach you dick -- pick this up, quite useful place to start. But if you're looking for something a bit more involved, you may as well just start with On the origin of Species, then check out The Selfish Gene.Also, Dawkins is just more entertaining -- so get to The Selfish Gene as well.But that said -- don't treat this as a war with religion. It's unnecessary, and intolerant, on both sides.

If you're on the fence when you commence reading this book you won't be by the time you've completed it. Or probably after two chapters. If you're a die-hard anti-evolutionists, this won't convince you. Because he acknowledges that, yes, there are questions and puzzles in the theory that have not been adequately addressed. But what he does extraordinarily well is turn the tables and ask creationists to make sesnse of the existing data without resorting to reasoning like, "the Creator is kinda funny that way. He just does wacky crazy unpredictable stuff that somehow perfectly fits a model of evolution. But it ain't evolution." And once that ploy is taken away, there are far more puzzles for creationists to explain than for evolutionists.

"Why Evolution Is True" is a good introduction to the topic of evolution. I didn't have a lot of foreknowledge about the subject before reading the book. It's difficult to write about the subject of evolution without using a lot of technical, scientific terms, but I found the content of this book very assessable and fairly easy to follow.Coyne primarily focuses on the non-human side of evolution, but he does provide some insight and evolutionary history and theory about how the nature of evolution does impact our biological, racial and gender differences.This is the sort of book that you will want to heavily underline, write notes in the margin, and follow up on additional reading and references.

I have nitpicks about his definitions of "fact" and "theory" (it's easy, people: a fact is a demonstrable thing (e.g. evolution is a fact in that we see alleles change over time) and a theory is the well-confirmed model that explains that thing (e.g. evolution (by natural selection) is also a theory, in that all of the evidence shows that from natural selection, species emerge). His definitions just muddled and confused the issue. I also got a bit lost in the embryology section, but that's probably more because it was on audiobook and I was driving.Other than those things, this was a great look at the evidence and explanation for evolution. If you don't know much, and have an aversion (for whatever reason) to Richard Dawkins, check this one out.

Though the writing is a bit on the dry side, 'Why Evolution Is True' is a clear summary of the overwhelming collection of evidence supporting evolution through natural selection. The book is a response to the significant portion of the US population who choose to throw their lot in with bronze age fairy tales over the mountain of paleontological, biological, and genetic evidence which stands in opposition to their creationist delusions. This book is also almost identical in scope and character to Richard Dawkins' 'The Greatest Show On Earth'. Though the subject matter is the same, I'd recommend Dawkins' book over Coyne's simply because the writing is more lively.

Jerry Coyne ' why evolution is true is a clearly well written and organized book supported with useful diagrams, provides an easy to understand summary on evolution theory , a good book for beginners .based almost entirely on naturalist perspective ( natural selection, analogy, anatomical and skeletal similarity, sexual selection, fossils records..) with overwhelming examples but leaving out the genetics , DNA studying, scientific analysis and controlled experiments , mathematics and statistics along with his focus on deffending evolution against creationism unfortunately affected on the scientific weight of the book .

I expected more of a direct address of Evolution vs. I.D, which was only a very minor feature of this book. Mostly, it's 250 pages of a lot of stuff I kind of already knew, but way more in depth. (Thanks to my AP bio teacher, Mr. Tassie!) This is a good book, but not exactly what I wanted. One favorite part is on p. 112, "The Engine of Evolution," where Coyne writes about honeybees killing giant hornets who invade their nests by raising their body heat and hovering close to the hornet in order to literally cook it to death. Bees are awesome.

Jerry Coyne's book is a clear and concise exposition of the vast and varied (overwhelming) evidence for Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection. Even for a well read layperson such as myself there was much that I was unfamiliar with. The constant march of evidence can get a bit tiresome, but then Coyne is engaged in defending science against that peculiarly American disease of Intelligent Design and Creationism. Highly recommended if you are not familiar with what evolution is, or why so many scientists regard it as the best confirmed theory we have.

his passion for the subject is clear, and, even though i knew evolution to be a solid hypothesis, i had no appreciation for its broad explanatory power. obscure factoids of evolution -- like plants with thousands of chromosomes -- finally make sense. my worldview and appreciation for life has been enriched quite a bit from a deeper engagement with this topic. coyne doesn't waste time with esoterica...every example he covers drives towards a beautiful & important facet of evolutionary theory. i loved this book.

He is preaching to the choir here, but no matter, he is doing it very well. The book is laid out in a very logical fashion and has all the characteristics of a well designed university course. It is written for somebody who may be encountering his arguments for the first time, yet it's not boring for the one who has read a lot about the topic. Ultimately, it may be the best and most clearly written book about evolution I have ever read.Well done.5+/5

The fact that I didn't discover anything new in this book is a proof that the French educational system is well adjusted and not delusional, as it should be everywhere. It was still nice to have facts and examples put together in one place. I'm not sure that it would make any creationist change their minds though, since that however clear and true the evidence are presented against their beliefs, they tend to cover their ears and sing-song 'i can't hear you I can't hear you'.

This is the first book I've read through in order to try and truly understand evolution. It didn't disappoint. Jerry Coyne does a great job in mapping out various concepts and ideas which support evolution and provides numerous examples/explanations in a fun, intellectually stimulating fashion to his readers. I'm inspired to read Richard Dawkins' works on this matter now and I highly recommend this book to anyone wanting to learn more of this subject.

Anyone with any doubts (particularly of the creationist variety) about the veracity of evolutionary theory should read this. It also works if you're just curious about the topic and haven't been exposed to it since high school biology or newspaper articles concerning the intelligent design "controversy." It's well written, accessible, and thorough.

I give the book stars for the quality of the factual information, but the book pandered too much to the side of individuals who already are firm in their belief of evolution. Perhaps if the author was more interested in changing the minds of individuals who believe in creationism, he wouldn't have been so condescending. You catch more flies with honey.

I like Jerry Coyne's style of writing; his language is easy to understand and his examples are straightforward. This book is a good read even if you are, like me, familiar with how evolution works because there are good examples of such workings (which often hide in my memory, too full with Monty Python quotes & Futurama episodes).

Very clear presentation of why evolution is true. I did not learn too much new because I have read many books on evolution, yet I was never bored, and found Jerry Coyne's examples to be very interesting. Strongly recommended to readers who would like to fill in some of the gaps in their knowledge (missing links;-)

I picked this up as a way to learn new things about evolution. Sadly, I did not learn as much as I'd expect to, since this is a book meant mostly for people who are not sure about evolution and are curious to learn about it. It is a collection of arguments to convince people that evolution is true, definitely not meant for people who are already familiar with the concept and want to learn more.

Excellent coverage of the multiple threads of evidence that make evolution of species as close to scientific fact as anything we know about our world. Very readable and able to be understood by anyone with a reasonable amount of education.

Meh. Straw-manned the Creationist position by using out-dated, caricatured arguments and religious accusations. Fun to read, however, because Coyne is obviously scared of the impending "religious takeover." A jumpy fellow.

If I had to recommend one book on evolution, esp for those who are scientifically illiterate, this would be the book. This books lays out the theory and the evidence backing it up clearly and understandably. I personally found it fascinating.

Those who know me may wonder why I would bother reading this (preaching to the choir.) But any book that so successfully explains why evolution is true is by definition explaining the most fascinating aspects of the natural sciences. An invigorating read.

This was a well-written and thorough review of the concepts behind and evidence for evolution. Having not taken biology since high school, a lot of this was new to me and really fascinating. Like a beautiful, complicated, billion-pieced puzzle. I had trouble putting the book down.

Two major problems with this book:One, if Mr Coyne wanted to convince people who believe in creationism why is he so offensive and rude?Two, for a book with such bold name - "Why evolution is TRUE" words like "perhaps, probably, might" are used too often.

Another excellent book explaining how evolution works and providing evidence in a way everyone can understand. If Richard Dawkins is too snarky for some, Jerry Coyne may be right for them. I loved this book. <3
Bible has ZERO truth about the creation of the world. Kent Hovind, Ken Ham and Ray Comfort can suck my atheist dick.
