I found this book very interesting. I haven’t heard all the arguments in favor of evolution, so I was curious what this man had to say. Dr. Coyne is a famous biology professor at the University of Chicago well known for his criticism of intelligent design. When he was asked in a recent interview about the credibility of creationism, Coyne said he didn't think creationism has any credibility: “It's not that we have two theories here: . . . one of them has explained the data, and the other was ruled out a hundred years ago.” When asked, what would you say to a creationist who read the book and remained unconvinced? Coyne said if the reader was unconvinced because Coyne’s book contravenes the Bible, then Coyne would tell him: “I’m sorry. I can't talk to you anymore. You can't be convinced by reason and evidence.”In his book, Coyne writes about the Asian Giant Hornet, “The world’s largest hornet, it has a two-inch body, fearsome jaws and a quarter-inch stinger that is lethal even to humans. This hornet is marvelously adapted to kill—it looks as though it were designed for mass slaughter.” Coyne’s use of the word designed caught my attention. I’m confused about this word when the theory holds there is no intelligence capable of designing anything. It seems like there is some residual perception, even with evolutionists, that there is some kind of intelligent design somewhere in the universe. I see this often in television documentaries on nature. They invariably attribute evolutionary change to some recognition of how it will benefit survival, which is an appeal to my intelligence that can recognize the value of the change, but there is no intelligence proposed by the theory that can recognize anything before the evolutionary change is made. I think even an evolutionist has trouble envisioning the world evolving devoid of intelligence.Coyne discusses how sex drives evolution, he writes: “Creationists could never explain why a super designer should produce gaudy feathers and heavy antlers in one sex and not in the other. Coyne mentions that Darwin had postulated sexual selection as a selection that increases a male’s chance of mating. Coyne writes: This is done in two ways. One way is to provide a means to fight off rivals; the other is a means to make a male more attractive. Coyne also discusses sexual selection in humans. An empress in Asia, for example, might have a penchant for men with straight black hair and almond shaped eyes. By creating a fashion, her preference spreads culturally to all her female subjects. Coyne continues that this ‘good-genes model’ remains the favorite explanation of sexual selection. These models assume that the evolution of sexual dimorphisms is driven simply by pre-existing biases in a female’s nervous system.”I think this ‘good genes model’ requires the intelligent choice of the female human, whom we all know is intelligent, but positing the same intelligence for animals is far fetched. I think an all-knowing creator guiding animals through instinct is a much better explanation. To me, Coyne’s argument presupposes that there is indeed a design that helps the organism in its survival. Animals recognize it and humans can certainly recognize it. That’s Coyne’s point, but where was the intelligence that recognized it beforehand? It is much more sensible for me to presume that God designed things this way.Even considering salmon that live their adult lives in the open ocean, then, after several years, as they approach the end of their lives, swim hundreds of miles across the open ocean to the river they were born in, and hundreds of miles up the river to spawn their eggs and sperm in the location where they first saw life. I can’t imagine a biological mechanism based on chemistry, hereditary traits, magnetism, or smell that can sufficiently explain this. Here again, it is much more sensible for me to presume that God designed things this way.Coyne writes that civilization began about 4000 BC. He goes on to say that “250 generations of civilized society lie atop 300,000 years during which we may have been hunters-gatherers living in small social groups.” Figuring 24 years per generation, would give 12,500 generations of hunter gatherers. Doesn’t anyone speculate on the extraordinary difference in capability between humans and pre-humans? Coyne writes: “We are the one creature to whom natural selection has bequeathed a brain complex enough to comprehend the laws of the universe. And we should be proud that that we are the only species that has figured out how we came to be.” I think it’s much more than a physical brain that explains the ability of humans to comprehend the laws of the universe. I stumble again on Coyne’s claim that “natural selection bequeathed humans a brain complex enough to comprehend the laws of nature.” Who is there to bequeath anything? The Theory of Evolution posits no intelligence at all in natural selection. Even Coyne’s use of the word laws jumps out at me. Attributing laws to random chance events is confusing. A law implies an intelligent lawgiver governing those chance events. If there is no intelligent lawgiver, why talk about laws? Sometimes those who argue against intelligence governing the universe use words that do not precisely get across their arguments.I think the spectacular rate of technological advance in human civilization during 250 generations compared to 12,500 generations of virtually no technological advance argues that there is a significant change in human nature compared to pre-humans. In my lifetime, I have seen technological advances I never would have believed possible. If one were to plot human technological advances against time starting at the beginning of civilization, with time being the vertical axis, the curve would start off horizontal and rapidly, exponentially, curve toward a vertical position. No animal displays that magnitude of advance in technology. Animals that have been on this earth far longer than humans show no advance at all. I think there is something different with humans. I think humans have a spiritual side to their nature as well as a physical side. I think humans are free persons given the ability to improve the conditions of their lives.I spite of my criticism of this book, I like to point out that I think the Theory of Evolution presents a believable scientific explanation of how the different species appeared in the world, and it could fit very well as a human understanding of how God did it, but to suppose that this theory proves that God did not create man is farfetched. Dr. Coyne was not present when man first came into existence? How would he know? All he has to go on are a few hundred bones of extinct hominoids and the testimony of Darwin. Darwin also was not present when man first came into existence, and Darwin had fewer fossil bones at his disposal than Coyne has. How does either one of them know how and why man first appeared? They are offering me their opinion that they want me to accept on faith in the accuracy of their word. I can’t verify their word. I wasn’t there myself, and I don’t have the resources or education to experiment on my own to verify what they say. The best I can do is to accept what they say on faith, accepting it on the credibility of their witness, but that’s not enough for me.The Biblical passage that evolutionists object to: that God made man from the clay of the Earth, isn’t clay composed of the same 98 elements that everything else in the universe is composed of? What is incorrect in saying God made man out of clay, or even if the wording were ‘out of the elements,’ or even ‘out of some pre-existing organism that had it’s origin from clay?’ All those statements claim substantially the same origin for the body of the first man.As far as credibility goes, the Biblical account of the origin of man comes from Moses. Moses was inspired by God to bring the Israelites out of slavery and to compose The Torah, the book containing the laws God wanted the Israelites to abide by. God also had Moses write the history of the Exodus and to compile the ancient traditions and history of the Israelites selecting, under God’s inspiration, which traditions Moses should preserve and which ones to reject. That makes God the authority behind what Moses included into the book. The Torah including Genesis has been accepted as the revealed word of God for some 3300 years. I prefer to place my faith in this witness by someone who was a prophet selected by God rather place my faith in what Darwin proposed 100 years ago.I have no problem accepting that the procedures God used appear to by very much like the Theory of Evolution describes. It’s Coyne’s insistence that this theory proves that God does not exist that I cannot accept. The only avenue any of us have to approach God is to believe the revelation he has made.I am unconvinced by Dr. Coyne’s arguments. I think a better explanation of the complexities of the world and the marvelous abilities of humans and animals is that God created the world and everything in the world, and guides animals through instinct that displays God’s intelligence, and God gifted humans with free will and a spiritual soul, which explains why humans are so much more advanced than animals.

This book is both helpful and frustrating.The scientific evidence is presented well. The chapters are well organized, the prose lucid, and the arguments are largely compelling. Coyne draws out his conclusions with interesting examples, and covers the most important issues relating to evolutionary science. I don't have much aversion to what IS in the book, from a scientific perspective. However, the two gripes I have with the book are significant. One deals with what what Coyne leaves OUT of the book and the other deals with what the book entails outside of the scientific realm. First, Coyne deals only with what he affirms, and ignores the views of other legitimate evolutionary scientists who see the science differently than he does. I understand that the book is a popular level treatment, and therefore is not going to feature a proper academic "lit review," but there is a bit more variation within the scientific community on some of these issues than Coyne lets on. This makes portions of the book misleading. Second, and this is my most significant problem with the book, I believe it was a mistake to make this book an apologetic for evolution. Coyne states that his purpose was two-fold; to elucidate the science at a popular level, which he largely succeeds at doing, and to offer "ammunition" against creationism. This apologetic approach was in some ways helpful, but in other ways severely flawed.The problems with Coyne's apologetics, in brief; First, he conflates belief/faith in a deity with creationism, and counters them as though they were the same thing (which they are not), without much thought to the differences between them, and with zero sophistication as to the varied beliefs of people of faith. Second, he makes use of the fallacious viewpoint that faith and reason (and religion and science) are incompatible; a fallacy that has been handily dealt with in a number of places. For example, there are major top 20 global universities that now offer post-grad degrees in "science and religion," that recognize the compatibility of the two, when both are viewed rightly. Coyne would have to convince entire academic institutions that their brilliant scholars are all off base, and he'd have to do so with deeply unsophisticated arguments attacking certain groups, like creationists, rather than attending to the real issues between faith and science. Third, his arguments regarding creationism, insofar as he conflates that with religion/faith, are highly caricatured and inaccurate. His rhetoric will convince no thinking person of faith, because he simply doesn't represent them fairly. Fourth, Coyne often pretends to think for a deity in the book, in unsophisticated ways. He often explains the science, quite well, and then concludes paragraphs by suggesting, "An intelligent creator would have no reason to do such a thing." Really? Where is your evidence for such a claim? He never offers any. Fifth, Coyne assumes the fairness, accuracy, and superiority of scientific findings, which is also fallacious, as reason based arguments for the limits of science stretch back as far as John Locke. Too often, Coyne blurs his lines by stretching beyond "Where the evidence likely takes us" into supposed sure-fire arguments regarding things not covered by the scientific method (historical and philosophical in nature).There is an irony in Coyne's approach that leads him into intellectual hypocrisy. He writes this book in part to counter the arguments of creationists that misunderstand evolution. But, while he succeeds in explaining the science very well, he conflates faith/religious categories that should not be conflated, showing that he misunderstands faith just as deeply as creationists misunderstand evolution (and then Coyne compounds this even more in his next book). My criticisms are lengthy, but let me be clear; I believe that the science in this book, which takes up 90% of the content, is instructive, helpful, and well argued. Had this simply been a popular level book explaining evolution, it would have been very good. But the 10% that makes up the paraenesis is so deeply flawed that it casts a shadow over the entire book. This makes it essentially unhelpful despite its positives.

Life is beautiful, amazing, and endlessly interesting.As a beneficent side-effect, Jerry Coyne - apart from wonderfully providing ample evidence for evolution, produces this feeling of interconnectedness between all living things. The Juan Fernandez firecrown, the beluga whale, the roundworm parasite, and homo sapiens, all share in this incredible and unlikely experience we call life.Why is this book important? Since the dawn of time, philosophers and worldly sages have sought to answer life’s most fundamental questions. Where do we come from? What is the meaning of life? Where are we headed? With asking these questions came great anxiety - after all, it was their quest for certainty, for knowledge, for things above and beyond the normal limits of human comprehension. In one way or another, consciously or subconsciously, every individual asks themselves this set of questions. Because of their universality, we could say they are the deepest questions of mankind. Wouldn’t it be great to have an answer to at least one of these? Well, evolutionary theory gives us one.Scientific theories and scientific research have two goals. Either discover new facts about the world, or test the hypothesis of previous theories, try and falsify them, and make them better and more robust if any holes in the theory are found. The least valuable goal of any scientific project is - scientific description. The most valuable - scientific prediction. And evolutionary theory is ripe with them. Predicting where and in which layer of rock fossils will be found. Predicting where and how old the fossils of transitional species will be. Correctly tracing down the phylogenetic tree to find common ancestry, and hundreds of predictions more - all serving as concrete evidence for evolution.Evolution is not just a theory. It is a theory of the same order as Newton’s theory of gravity, or the theory of Copernican heliocentrism. These theories are practically manifested in our everyday lives. You can’t say that Copernican heliocentrism is just a theory and then use a GPS to get somewhere. You can’t say that the theory of gravity is just a theory and live in a building. It is very easy to mistake the word theory in its everyday usage with its scientific usage. A theory in science is like a general in the army. It is of the highest order.It was very interesting telling other people about the evidence for evolution. Try it, it ends up being a conversation in which, in my experience, 90% of the time people are shocked in disbelief. Some babies are born with small tails? What!? The stages of embryonic development in humans resemble the development of embryos of other vertebrates, in the same order we evolved from them? Impossible! Whatever questions you might have had about evolution and the mechanism that drives it - natural selection - will be answered in this book. It is my experience that people fall back on superstition, in situations where they simply don’t know enough of the facts to make their case.There is another, deeper reason, why people choose to firmly hold on to a 200-year old worldview. It is because the validity of the theory of evolution has very personal consequences for individuals. Believing in it, is terrifying. Instead of a creator that has a plan for each and every part of our lives, and the universe as a whole, we are left with a random, material, mechanistic process that doesn’t give a shit about whether we are happy, hell, it doesn’t even care if we stay alive - after we have done our reproductional duties.On the other side of the coin, evolution tells another, beautiful story. It is a story of prolonged darkness (4.6 billion years - to be exact), and a very brief moment of light. I am speaking, of course, about the light that consciousness brings to human existence. An analogy from this book tells us that, if we are to put the entire history of the Earth in one year, the first life form would appear by the end of March, and human beings would appear on the 31st of December, at 6:oo PM. This is the part we get to participate in. The contingency, the randomness, the luck we had to have to be here - is incredible. We don’t get to choose, we get to do whatever we can to enjoy the light. C'est la vie, my friends!

This is one the best books on evolution that I read and it certainly clarified a number of issues for me. Coyne writes well and provides full explanations in easy to understand language. He has an uncanny ability to anticipate questions: many a times I found myself reading a paragraph and forming questions like "...but what about...?" only to find this same question with its answer a few paragraphs below - sometimes it was unnerving!Coyne is also an unbiased writer as he will tell you whether or not the evidence exist even for the things that he has developed a preference. For example, although he seems to favour the "good gene" model as an explanation of sexual selection (i.e., females select males who have, in their estimation, good genes) he also says that there are only two studies that support this theory, while many other studies do not.The book covers the gamut of the evidence in support of evolution: genetic, laboratory studies, the fossil record, vestigial organs, embryology, mathematical models, accurate predictions of the theory, geographic distribution of species, replication of evolutionary outcomes by mixing species that were suspected to form the parents of the new species and finally bad design (i.e., evolutionary left-overs the are not optimal biologically and would not have been there if someone had created that species from scratch, e.g., the descenting human testicle). The evidence is not only overwhelming, but robust. Which raises the question "how could any sane person not accept the theory"? Or "how could there still be controversy as to whether or not it is true?"...more on this momentarily.The only negative thing I have to say about this book is a statement that Coyne makes twice (probably an oversight). He says that "the theory of evolution" is a fact. But it is not "the theory" that is a fact but rather "evolution". The theory contains more than just facts that prove evolution . It contains explanations about how and why evolution happens and as he says there is still controversy about the relative importance of the mechanisms that bring about evolution.I would also like to make a semantic point about the discussion on randomness versus non-randomness in evolution by selection. Coyne says that the genetic mutations (both incorrect copies of genes and gene drift) that are necessary to create a genetically variant population and hence enable evolution are random, but natural selection is not. Well, if a population is genetically variant and a random natural phenomenon happens (the example that Coyne provides is rise of the land bridge between north and south America), then which mutations are stuck on which side of the Panama canal is also random and hence their evolution happens because of two random events: a) the geological event and b) the location at which the species with the particular mutations found itself stuck by chance. So it is not clear to me what we mean here by "natural selection" being none-random. Yes, given a distribution of genetic variants and an environment, then natural selection will select the fitter genes. But both the location of the "fitter" genes (being on the east or the west side of the Panama canal) and the geological event are random events - natural selection has to work with what it has it cannot make up things! Furthermore, "fitter" is a relative concept, not an absolute concept. A gene is fitter given what else is in that environment. But what other species got isolated on the west side of Panama canal was also a random event and natural selection may have made a different selection if some of those species did not happen to get isolated by chance. In any case this is not an important issue.I now come to the issue of Intelligent Design and the resistance to the evolutionary evidence by those who believe in ID. I would classify the ID supporters into two groups: the first group consists of snake-oil salesmen. They sell ID not because they believe in it, but because they profit from doing so. Although these guys are morally despicable and annoying, they are not the real problem since if the activity becomes unprofitable they will simply abandon it and move on to the next con-job. Then we have the second group who really believes in ID. Michael McGuire in his book Believing: The Neuroscience of Fantasies, Fears, and Convictions mentions the case of a woman patient of his who, although rational in other issues, believed that her parents were not her real parents. And she believed this despite of all the evidence provided to her by her parents, grandparents, the hospital and other friends and relatives who were around when she was born! According to McGuire, we form beliefs all the time about everything and the job of our brain is to reduce the distance between evidence and the belief. And if the evidence do not exist, our brain will make it up. But why should our brains make up evidence in support of ID? I would argue that this is so because of the costs and benefits involved. Some people's belief in God is tightly connected to their need to believe in afterlife. And this issue is much more important to them than the belief in evidence-based explanations of the origin of species. As such, these folks' brains will make up whatever they need to maintain their belief in God and hence afterlife.So, are these folks a lost cause then, similar in nature to people who suffer from schizophrenia? I think so.Is there a point in trying to argue with them rationally? Trying to convince them that, say, morality is not going to suffer if we believe in evolution and that people who believed in ID from 4,000 BC to about 1945 were severely more morally depraved and brutal to each other then today's atheists or liberal-minded people? I don't think so. It is just a waist of time and energy.So is there anything we could do? Yes, I think the solution is not to try to convince them of their erroneous beliefs by rational arguments and evidence, but rather to give them a way out so they can believe in ID and evolution at the same time! How is this possible? Well, evolution says nothing about the rise of the first cell organism. Where and How did it come about? So we could point them to a theory that says that God knew exactly what he was doing when he created the conditions that gave rise to the first single-cell organism. This was the "divine spark" that was needed to start evolution! And this is what the Bible means when it talks allegorically about Adam and Eve. The rest took care of itself and God did not really have to be involved in the minutia of evolution since he knew the outcome anyway (let's not forget that he omniscient). This way there is no contradiction between the theory of evolution and God's books, since evolution does not try to explain that part. But, one could argue, this will only push the inevitable conflict into some distant point in the future. It does not solve anything. True, but in the meantime we can go on teaching evolution at schools and not teaching ID...and who knows what will happen after several generations have been brought up in this model.Finally, evolutionary biologists need to get a bit more critical of evolutionary psychologists who are spoiling the field for them. Coyne talks about them and their "Just so" stories, but we need more of that. These guys should not even be considered as scientists. And perhaps the language needs to improve a bit. Although Coyne explains the randomness and purposelessness of evolution, other than genetic propagation, sometimes he even sounds like natural selection or species adaptations have some kind of intentionality. Even the words "natural selection" imply that "nature" has some kind of purpose or intention. Maybe it is time to leave Darwin's words behind?

For some reason, Evolution is a touchy subject. You find people sometimes that doubt its authenticity, decrying it as ‘only a theory.’ Usually, these people don’t know what a theory is when it applies to science. I can say this because Gravity is also a theory, and I don’t see people nonchalantly floating off into space. There isn’t an alternative to the theory of Gravity unless you are really into Aristotle and never heard of Isaac Newton or Albert Einstein. Relativity is a theory as well and we use that all the time for GPS and Satellites and things.However, Why Evolution Is True points out some interesting things about human nature that I did not consider before. Apparently, the idea of natural selection and anything that doesn’t involve a creator god challenges the identity of a person who believes in a creator god. Why Evolution is True is a book that I really enjoyed a great deal. It provides evidence for all of its statements. This is something that I find preferable to throwing up your hands and making up a magic sky man.Let’s go back a bit though. This book provides tons of evidence for all of the statements it makes. It discusses the history of Evolution and how it was thought to be a thing but they couldn’t provide a mechanism by which it occurred until Charles Darwin came along. Once science had the mechanism of natural selection it really took off. Everywhere you look you can find evidence that it is the truth.The author Jerry A Coyne carefully assembles his arguments against every parry that a creationist could invent. Take the idea of certain bacteria having a little molecular motor, or the old favorite of the complexity of the eye. Coyne argues that for each event it isn’t necessary to produce an eye from nothing, just that you have to have something functional that doesn’t hinder the organism. We learn about sexual selection and tons of other things along the way. Coyne even discusses the idea of molecular biology and how it is helped along by our more advanced science.If you are a staunch creationist you probably won’t change your mind at this book, but I thought it was very compelling. Then again, I don’t know why you would want to read this book as a staunch creationist unless you were looking to argue. I could be wrong though.

Marvelous discussion of all the points that irk creationists no end. In these days of climate change and, it seems, all things science denial it's important for believers to be grounded in the facts. One picky point about Dr. Coyne is his belief that scientists should not leave the lab to participate in protests against fear-mongers and alternate fact spewers. America is trending in the opposite direction from most of the rest of the industrialized world.Notes: 1 Evolution matters because it is personal.1 Resistance stems largely from religion.5 Evolution is genetic change over time.4 Gradualism says major changes take thousands or millions of years.5 Splitting or speciation.7 99% of species go extinct leaving no descendants.15 A theory must be testable and make verifiable predictions.35 Only need transitional fossil species not distinct missing link.60 Creationists don't like vestiges because it shows animals evolved.68 Dead genes for smell in dolphins refutes creationism.76 Embryonic development and ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny.88 Biogeographic evidence so powerful that creationists don't contest it.81 Robin Williams observation about bad design and waste treatment plant next to recreation area.90 Convergent evolution is the same adaptation in different anmimals- for example gliding on the flying squirrel and the sugar glider.108 Creationists hate the logioc of island biogeography.123 Genetic drift is another type of evolution but random.123 Genetic drift is the opposite of natural selection.148 Sexual dimorphism is differences between sexes of same species.160 Extreme sexual dimorphism correlates to greater competition for mates.169 Darwin actually doesn't address speciation.176 Genes don't arise to fill a niche.188 Polyploid speciation.215 Cultural change can produce genetic change.219 Due to cultural change we are going downhill genetically.225 Evolution doesn't give us a reason for existence and that bothers people.

I was raised in a fundamentalist home who believed evolution was wholly untrue. I vividly remember questioning my teachers in middle and high school about different conflicting or unproven aspects of creationism. Eventually I decided that if I were the only Christian on earth to believe that evolution was true, I was okay with that. After all, isn't it more amazing to imagine a God capable of creating a world of natural resources, physics, chemistry, math, and pure chance that culminates into the earth we know today than a God who simply placed all that exists on earth 6,000 years ago and was done? Fortunately, as a now Catholic, my religion does not condemn evolution (although it does still condemn other widely held beliefs). But why am I talking about my personal religion, rather than this book? Because that is what the belief in evolution actually comes down to- one's self. If you are interested in evolution, because it might be true or because you want a better understanding in order to show its fallacies, I highly suggest you begin here with Coyne.This book lays out clearly and logically every(?) facet necessary to understanding evolutionary theory. I do have a background in science (B.S. in Biology), but I think anyone of high school level knowledge can understand this book. This book is valuable because it is a current and simple description of evolution and natural selection- everything that one *should* learn in school in one, illustrated book. This book is also *actually* interesting as is demonstrated by it being one of the only nonfiction books that I have completed.P.S. Even if evolution is false- God created us all 6,000 years ago- isn't evolution still an extremely helpful tool that we can use to better understand God's world? P.P.S. It is okay to doubt. The disciple Thomas doubted and Jesus still loved him.

This book is enjoyable and well-written, and contains a lot of useful information about evolution. It covers almost every argument in favor of evolution that one could imagine. My only critique of the book is that Coyne uses the "bad design" argument early on, and I object modestly to this point, as someone who believes in evolution. While I don't think the "design" of the body is proof of intelligent design or favors creationism, I don't think "bad design" necessarily works against it, either.The human body may be a lot like coding. Sometimes, things just work and we leave it alone. Sometimes, removing or changing one line or instance can have unforeseen consequences on the rest of the code. Coyne uses the example of the circuitous path of the laryngeal nerve, which is commonly pointed to, as an example of bad design. Yet, we know that this nerve innervates other parts of the anatomy on its path, and that innervation itself is complicated and still not wholly understood by neuronatomists. He argues that the long path of the laryngeal nerve makes it more susceptible to damage, and yet if it connected directly to the brain from the larynx, whatever it would have innervated along its former path would still require innervation. Therefore, it would seem to me that there would just be something else there potentially susceptible to similar damage.I think the case for evolution is powerful enough that speculative and subjective ideas about "bad design," when there is still so much we don't know, even about the brain, are unnecessary. I favor abandoning the argument and sticking to the other substantial proofs of evolution. Biogeography alone makes a better case than most metaphysical or any "bad design" arguments.I would rate this book a 4.5/5 if I could. Great work.

Truthfully I didn't read all of this book. It was for a class and we only read certain chapters, but I read enough to know I hated it. It was pretty basic and told in a boring way so I wasn't learning anything new, nor was I entertained. But maybe this book isn't for me? After all I am in my second year in college as a Biology major. Logically I already know a lot about evolution (So why did my professor force us to read this book then? I wish I knew) However, the people who might not know this information and find in themselves the desire to hear the basics of the arguments for evolution told simply will be turned off by this book. Coyne is very condescending in his writing about anyone who has even the slightest doubt in evolution or belief in a higher power (even if they still believe in evolution, which many people do). I'm firmly agnostic (raised Lutheran) and I was still kind of offended by how rude he seemed about spirituality. I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone who is interested in evolution. Either you already know all the information and it'll just be boring and slightly aggravating to read. Or you will likely be offended and turned off from considering any of the arguments in favor of evolution.

Lots of interesting info in here about a whole host of creatures. And a number of compelling arguments that suggest at least some aspects of evolution are true. Creationists should not be dismissive of the science behind evolution. I appreciated him best when he focused on biology and paleontology and stayed away from topics like God and ethics—clearly not his area of expertise. But the polemical tone was heavy-handed, and he seemed to think that he proved more than he really had. As an open-minded Christian coming to this book I would think I am his primary audience. But my biggest question about evolution is this: is it possible, or probable, that mindless forces could by accident produce the countless mutations necessary to have the abundance of species in our planet? Amazingly he did not answer this question. I think the reason was because his main premise that natural selection is the engine of evolution is faulty. Natural selection is the steering wheel of evolution, but natural selection is not the engine. The car doesn't move without the mutations. The question "Where did the mutations come from?" is the heart of the matter, and he didn't address it for me.

Being a Catholic, at first, I had a hard time reading this book, mostly due to Coyne's very blunt words. However, i quickly became fascinated by the extensive research and accurate science he provided upon a wide range of subtopics to the theory of evolution. I read this book alongside Shubin's "Your Inner Fish" and they are great companions as Coyne makes reference on a few occasions to Shubin's discovery of Tiktaalik. Overall, this book has opened my eyes to the science of how all beings were created. In the end, Coyne has insightful and spiritual words towards how evolution does not guide our future, but merely explains the past. I recommend this book to anyone who is interested in knowing a little more about the theory of evolution. It has been a great read for me and has opened me up intellectually. If you are a catholic and are worried about how this book could impact your faith, I encourage you to read the Encyclical Humani Generis of the Holy Father Pius XII (you can google it to find the document), in which the Holy Father speaks on behalf of the church in relation to evolution.

This book definitely helped my spotted knowledge of the fact of Evolution. It supports the many points that atheists and philosophers have made as to why Creationism and "Intelligent Design" just doesn't make any sense at all when the Earth and its past and present inhabitants are genuinely acknowledged and studied."Intelligent Design" is especially nonsensical. It is an easy excuse for any person to accept the excellent arguments presented for Evolution (and why the theory has been verified) yet still refuse to let go of an imaginary, simultaneously all-knowing and idiotic creator. If a god truly did create the Earth and man, he's an idiot.Because of all the detail involved in this book (so many references to thousands/millions/billions of years ago), I wish it would have contained more charts, graphs, images, etc. It's not an easy task to think in seemingly negative terms of X many years ago. It's like making references to BCE (Before Common Era, or BC) by taking the difference in relation to now. If it had those charts, this book would get five stars. (I should look for that book...)

This is one of the best book to understand and know clearly about complex evolution of animals in our planet. The language is very strong and easy to understand. Anyone regardless of his education background can pick this book and can enjoy a journey through the world of fossil and evolution.The magnum opus book about evolution is surely Charles Darwin's The origin of Species. But the book was written even before the discovery of basic genetics. So many theories proposed by Mr. Darwin can seem pretty hard and preposterous to get from that book. But this one is basically a rewritten version of the origin along with modern science and genetical data proving the validity of the theories. It also goes further by proposing modern theories regarding evolution and what might we find out in future. The writer did a great job including easy pictures and maps instead of hard mathematical data which might confuse the young learners.I would say, if you are really interested about evolution and what actually triggered the long lasting debate about our origin, you need to read this book thoroughly.

In  Why Evolution is True,  Jerry A. Coyne lays out evidence for evolution, and does a fine job of it. He addresses common objections to evolution and explains where they fall down. He acknowledges the limitations regarding what the fossil record can provide, and explains why that's not a problem. In the last chapter of the book, he addresses the common fear that belief in evolution will result in a less moral society.Overall, the book is well written. The author makes his case. If I have one complaint about the book, it's that he's a little defensive about it. He complains that no other science has to defend its assertions like evolution. This is not true. In my physics and engineering classes in high school and college we replicated experiments demonstrating the accuracy of the laws of electromagnetics. But nobody fears that the laws of electromagnetics will result in a less moral society.

An enlightening book. It teaches us the basic ideas of evolution, backed up by evidence. This book teaches us that evolution is not something to be afraid of, for it might cause as to act like beasts, (because we evolved from them) but it shows us that we are indeed evolved -- better. It merely shows us where we come from, and the wondrous laws of nature that acted upon species in order to form a biological complex specimen such as humans. I also like the fact that the author is not afraid to say that science doesn't have all the answers, for now. Science, like species, are contiually evolving. Just because we don't know something right now, that we have to use the "God of the Gaps" argument. It just means that we have to strive to learn better about our world and how it works; including evolution. We are lucky that natural selection evolved us brains that can actually comprehend its role in our evolution, and I hope that with the same brain, all people will realize that evolution is not "just a theory", but is a scientific fact.

You may not remember every bit of evidence presented in this lucid and vivid narrative but the wonder will surely remain. Somewhere in the book he mentions how man evolved to make sense of just about thirty years and goes on to take us slowly but surely, through evidence after evidence, all the way back to the Cambrian fossils to a more recent 7 million years ago - when early man emerged, branching out from apes, and the other wondrous evolution stories in between - from fish to reptiles to birds to mammals. All held together with that most remarkable intellectual breakthrough, Darwin's natural selection. Even if all this common knowledge or the gist of it is, this book is so much more than just an essential and relevant argument for a world where a significant population is still unconvinced. It is a celebration of the journey made so far, of how we came to be. Dotted with anecdotes and quotes, strewn with facts and overwhelming evidence, and replete with wonder - altogether a very engrossing saga. Loved it!

This is an excellent overview of the multitude of evidence in support of the theory of evolution. Coyne's writing is easily accessible, interesting, and to the point. I would recommend this to anyone who wants a refresher on evolution, or who has not been exposed to evolutionary theory since high school (or who never even were exposed in high school...). I will say that Coyne is very heavy-handed in his rebukes against creationists/intelligent design-ers - since I was primarily reading this book to better understand evolutionary research, rather than combatting creationists, I found those parts a bit tiresome. However, they are easily glossed over if you are more interested in the research itself. I really did like how Coyne frames so much of the book by making a prediction based on evolutionary theory and then listing the evidence that supports the prediction. It clearly shows the robustness of Darwin's proposition and how, over time, it has been supported and supported to the point that evolution is no longer "just" a theory, but scientific fact.

Ahh... the subject of evolution, or to some people "How we are/are not descended from primates because that would alter our worldview of ourselves and how important we think we are in this world." I gave this book five stars simply because of the fact that it meets the following criteria: 1.) The writing is amazingly good when it comes to taking something complex and intricately detailed and being able to bring it down to a level that the average everyday person can read, digest, and understand. 2.) A wealth of supporting facts and evidence is given in support of the main ideas that run through this book. 3.) Opposite and contravening opinions are addressed, logically and in a methodical and systematic manner. The book does not so much decry as debunk by showing how certain ideas/concepts/issues that are used by people who don't like this idea (mainly creationists and the like) simply do not hold water when placed under scientific review and, more interestingly, common sense and logical deduction. 4.) Painstaking effort is taken to illustrate and delineate the most critical and important links between theories, ideas, evidence, process, and eventual product of evolution. The author goes to great pains and lengths to "connect the dots" as it were when showing why the theory of evolution is more than just a theory. He even addresses the controversy surrounding the usage of the word theory, by placing it in its proper context as it is used in the scientific community.5.) This book does not talk down. Instead, it takes competing ideas, assumes their posits are true, and then proceeds to show the gaps/deficiencies in the logic/process/evidence/etc., widely documented, and explain how such gaps/deficiencies either disprove the competing idea, or make it less tenable and usable than the one that is accepted by the scientific community. 6.) While the topic of creationism is addressed, by name, at numerous points in the book, it never once felt when I was reading it as if it was an "anti-creationism" work. Instead it felt like the author was trying to be as objective as possible and give the idea as much benefit of the doubt as well, only to then proceed and expose the flaws to the point espoused by creationism. In other words, instead of seeming like it was screaming "pro-evolution" at the top of its lungs, the book seemed instead like a patient, logical, rational teacher that was taking two screaming kids and correcting their understanding of the topic being fought over in a calm, sensible, and educated manner. Some people, regardless of whatever they are shown/told or otherwise, are always going to believe that humankind was the way we are since day one, and that the earth is thousands of years old and not the billions that the fossil and geological record say we are. This book is not for them. This book is for people who want to understand the idea more, the controversy surrounding the idea, or seek illumination regarding this topic in order to be able to more intelligently discuss the topic (or be able to understand why it is such a critical issue in today's educational curriculum). With such issues today as gene treatment therapies based on race emerging as hot button issues (and that one in particular because it can smack of racism when it is actually using scientific data to pinpoint and illuminate issues that seem to be endemic to a particular ethnicity, issues that have developed over time due to geographical isolation and the changes in their evolution that developed as a result of said isolation), it is more important than ever for people to know and understand this issue today, clearly and sharply. All teachers who teach evolution should also read this book, simply because it might give them additional advice and/or info in the event that they are ever challenged in their teaching of evolution by parents or anyone else who doesn't buy into it. Finally, to anyone on the fence regarding this issue - this book will hopefully help you understand the issue better, and place it into a better perspective of understanding. Moreover, it will hopefully get you off the fence and into the camp of at least seeing why this issue is so critical to understand and why it is so important to not bend to the pressure of people who want the issue removed from school curriculums. Now, for my own personal note: this book has a quote on the dustcover by Richard Dawkins that, while sounding a bit harsh, is one that I can readily agree with as it regards this book. As I said at the beginning of this review, the reason why a lot of people have issues with this topic is because it challenges their notion of being "special" in this world, of being nothing more than the product of random chance and luck. The simple fact that we have, as a race, managed to come this far while everything has been so dependent on luck and chance is nothing short of amazing - think of it as winning at the blackjack table in Vegas each and every time you bet a lot of money, even if now and then you miss a small hand. This book openly admits that the evidence used in it is not complete. It also goes on to state that even though that is the case, if the model holds true, then future predictions can and should work - and then it goes on to show specific examples of just that. It admits the limits of its own knowledge and works the best it can with what it has to show, the whole while addressing the gaps and saying how new evidence may one day overturn the model and necessitate reworking it into something new. Most amazingly, it has no problem with this at all. Such honesty about who we are and how we got here is not only rare but, more importantly, should be valued. Overall, a book that should be read by anyone who wants to understand the idea more, the controversy surrounding it, or looking for clarification and illumination on the subject.

This is a great pop science read even if you only have a passing interest in evolutionary biology. Possibly one of the best on the subject. An absolute recommend to anyone who might at all be interested. Proponents of ID might feel personally attacked but let's be honest, they don't leave much room for alternatives to their worldview and this or any book isn't going to change their mind.

One thing I really liked is the description of how evolutionary theory predicts facts that have been confirmed by further research. I also really enjoyed the last chapter on what the theory of evolution means for humans and their morality. Great book: it gave me exactly the knowledge I needed.

The reason: because there are still large numbers of people in our society who are skeptical about evolution. As Coyne explains, evolution is as solidly established as any scientific fact and is not "just a theory" as some non-scientists would like to believe. "[...] we should be proud that we are the only species that has figured out how we came to be." This is an outstanding book. Excellent overview of many different aspects of evolution, written in a very accessible way. What an incredible read. Jerry Coyne does an elaborate and concise job on explaining why evolution as a 'theory' is no theory but in fact a law and scientific knowledge. Taking its readers through the history of earth and the origins of evolution as a studied concept, Coyne makes it impossible to deny the process of evolution. Every chapter was full of facts that I otherwise never have come across in documentaries or books, so it was great to have a book dedicated to showing evolution in several species and understanding the chronology of it all, as well as the reasoning, the mutations, the 'mistakes' and even the role that evolution has in modern day culture and biography! Definitely a must read for the avid fan of science!

Jerry A. Coyne from the University of Chicago is a distinguished biologist of Speciation fame and a well-known figure in the intelligent design vs. evolution debate. He for some reason felt obliged to lay out the evidence for evolution, but unlike the one mentioned above, which is a highly technical textbook (co-authored with H. Allen Orr) and an embarrassingly difficult read even for professionals, Why Evolution Is True is a delightful book designed for the average reader.Isn't this so-called ID-evolution debate already settled? Apparently not. Not in America, at any rate. While it's not really an issue in Europe, a great number of people in the United States flatly reject evolution and literally interpret the Bible as the ultimate truth.But here's the thing: the evidence for evolution is overwhelming. It's there for all to see. Paleontology, geology, plate tectonics, biogeography, comparative anatomy, genetics, molecular biology - all these disciplines have their share to add to the ever-growing pile of evidence. You have to be blind or just plain stupid to deny it.At any rate, Dr. Coyne makes his attempt to impart this intelligence to the lay people. After explaining in the first chapter what evolution is, in the following chapters he makes his case clearly with numerous examples from the above disciplines. Chapter 2 deals with fossils, how paleontologists work, radioactive dating methods, prominent transitional fossils like Tiktaalik (fish to amphibian), Archaeopteryx (reptile to bird), Indohyus (an artiodactyl ancestor of whales). This is really just an excerpt. There are a lot more.Chapter 3 happens to contain my favourite example, one from ontogenesis. Not the easiest to understand, but I hadn't known about it before. I recommend medical students pop this to their anatomy teacher: why the heck our left recurrent pharyngeal nerve goes all the way down to the heart and comes back only to innervate the larynx?The answer lies in ontogenesis and common ancestry:"One of nature's worst designs is shown by the recurrent laryngeal nerve of mammals. Running from the brain to the larynx, this nerve helps us speak and swallow. The curious thing is that it is much longer than it needs to be. Rather than taking a direct route from the brain to the larynx, a distance of about a foot in humans, the nerve runs down into our chest, loops around the aorta and a ligament derived from an artery, and then travels back up to connect to the larynx. It winds up being three feet long. In giraffes the nerve takes a similar path, but one that runs all the way down that long neck and back up again: a distance fifteen feet longer than the direct route! When I first heard about this strange nerve, I had trouble believing it. Wanting to see for myself, I mustered up my courage to make a trip to the human anatomy lab and inspect my first corpse. An obliging professor showed me the nerve, tracing its course with a pencil down the torso and back up to the throat. This circuitous path of the recurrent laryngeal nerve is not only poor design, but might even be maladaptive. That extra length makes it more prone to injury. It can, for example, be damaged by a blow to the chest, making it hard to talk or swallow. But the pathway makes sense when we understand how the recurrent laryngeal nerve evolved. Like the mammalian aorta itself, it descends from those branchial arches of our fishlike ancestors. In the early fishlike embryos of all vertebrates, the nerve runs from top to bottom alongside the blood vessel of the sixth branchial arch; it is a branch of the larger vagus nerve that travels along the back from the brain. And in adult fish, the nerve remains in that position, connecting the brain to the gills and helping them pump water. During our evolution, the blood vessel from the fifth arch disappeared, and the vessels from the fourth and sixth arches moved downward into the future torso so that they could become the aorta and a ligament connecting the aorta to the pulmonary artery. But the laryngeal nerve, still behind the sixth arch, had to remain connected to the embryonic structures that become the larynx, structures that remained near the brain. As the future aorta evolved backward toward the heart, the laryngeal nerve was forced to evolve backward along with it. It would have been more efficient for the nerve to detour around the aorta, breaking and then re-forming itself on a more direct course, but natural selection couldn't manage that, for severing and rejoining a nerve is a step that reduces fitness. To keep up with the backward evolution of the aorta, the laryngeal nerve had to become long and recurrent. And that evolutionary path is recapitulated during development, since as embryos we begin with the ancestral fishlike pattern of nerves and blood vessels. In the end, we're left with bad design."The following chapters deal with the geography of life, how animals came to live in the separate continents, island biogeography, bees killing giant hornets by heating them up to 80 degrees centigrade, evolution in the test tube, drug resistance, a whole chapter on sexual selection, speciation (the process of distinct species formation), population genetics, human evolution (including Homo floresiensis, the hobbit), etc.All in all, a profoundly satisfying read, a rare gem in the market of popular science books. Last words:"We are the one creature to whom natural selection has bequeathed a brain complex enough to comprehend the laws that govern the universe. And we should be proud that we are the only species that has figured out how we came to be."

I still have a hard time comprehending how some people still deny evolutionary evidence. When I set out to read this book, I'd just come off reading the Jurassic Park books and was interested in comparing the novels' "science" to that of our own. This book carefully maps out an argument for evolution, one which is completely convincing and brought me back to an anthropology class back in uni. I still can't believe people argue against evolution, especially in our day, but Coyne argues against creationist views and backs up his arguments with research and facts instead of using sarcastic wordplay.

Considering that Jerry Coyne intended this book to be accessible to the general public, I found it a greatly written book, as Jerry Coyne easily weaves in the difficult concepts without throwing in too many technical terminologies. This book does not attempt to disprove God, but lambasts the notion put forth by creationists (and Intelligent Designers) that evolution is false in its entirety.The chapters on speciation were a great read, as certain forms of speciation that are less known (such as hybridization) are easily tackled and brought forth with clarity.Great read and an educational book!

Great book in general, I learned a lot about the tangible evidences of evolution. I think genetics do explain and support evolution enough, yet it remains a challenging task to convince people about evolution since they want something tangible, not just a comparison between sequences of genes.I read this as an effort to present evolution in a classroom to other students (I am a student myself, studying CS, nothing related to biology really) since they were all curious about it and, unfortunately, very misinformed. I think the book served my purpose well, and of course, I got to learn a lot for myself, too and I'm ever more interested in the topic.

With the amount of resistance that a solid and provable scientific theory gets in this country, one would think that we are still living in the religiously dogmatic medieval ages. This is partly why evolutionary Biologist, Dr. James Coyne set out to write this book. One of the main premises of Coynes work is to clear up any confusion that persists in the public eye concerning the natural evolution of species through the catalysts of natural selection and speciation.  With an accessible style, Coyne presents an overwhelming case for Evolution as being a demonstratable fact. Besides the amount of information that Coyne sets down before the reader, his ability to explain such complex topics with ease sets this book apart from the rest. It is delightful how Coyne can narrate all of the information without being unintelligibly abstract to the layman.   Throughout this work, Coyne demonstrates that evolutionary theory makes predictions that are consistently borne out by the data—basic requirements for a scientific theory to be valid. Although being respectful of those who promote intelligent design and creationism (i.e claims that each species, especially humans - are the product of a separate creative act by an intelligent designer ), Coyne uses the extensive scientific data at his disposal to demolish any thought that creationism is supported by any physical evidence, while also explaining why those ideas fall outside the bounds of science. Dr. Coyne does not hesitate from periodically pointing-out where it is most relevant that creationism simply offers no scientific explanation in attempting to refute Evolution, while dodging other ramifications .It is sometimes even humorous while reading Coyne presenting many examples of physical proofs that are employed to clarify a concept - to suddenly find it pitted against creationism and how it tries to argue with the presented information. It is refreshing to see Coyne demonstrating the flaws in these creationist viewpoints or objections not with rhetoric, but with well chosen evidence. . .For example - One of the myths about evolution that Coyne dispells is the claim that there are lots of "gaps" in the fossil record to explain how complex organs such as the eye or wings of a bird can evolve by natural selection, or that there are irreducible gaps between species of animals that are supposed to have evolved from the other. Coyne finds no problem in citing the numerous cases of transitional fossils that have been found (such as the fish-terapod link), which do bridge the irreducible gaps that the creationist critics of evolution have asserted could never be bridged. Coyne does this repeatedly when addresses human evolution in particular, and shows how the fossilized bones of hominin ancestors fit perfectly into the predicted intermediate forms. features accessible chapters on: - What evolution is, and is not (specific defining features, testability, etc.) - The fossil record (including specific examples and discussion of transitional forms and lineages (dinosaur feathers, whales, etc).- Specific predictions of Evolution and their fulfillment's - Vestigial and atavistic features (e.g. human tails and appendices, and whale pelvises and dolphin legs) - Examples of "Bad design" which renders the concept of an "intelligent designer" absurd (e.g. flat fish skulls and eyes, and the route of the vagus nerve in humans, as well as problems with both genders' reproductive systems) - Developmental oddities (e.g. dolphin embryos beginning growth of hind legs that are later changed, human embryonic growth and subsequent absorption of tails, as well as the growth and loss of a full coat of hair).- Pseudogenes - Biogeography- Specific examples of evolution in action, both in nature and in the lab (via natural selection)- Genetic drift - Artificial selection (e.g. domestic dogs, agriculture, etc).- Speciation  Coyne is also clear (in his final chapter; Evolution redux) of the limits to evolutionary thinking. . .This is where Coyne directly addresses the concept often advanced by religious fundamentalists that an acceptance of evolution must lead to immorality, concluding that evolution tells us where we came from, not where we can go. By the end of the book the basic areas of evolutionary investigation clearly demonstrate that the material evidence confirms evolution, not creationism/ID. Readers looking to understand the case for evolution and searching for an truthful response to many of the most common creationist claims should find everything they need in this book, which is clearer and more comprehensive than the many others on the subject that I had read in the past. With Coynes consistently using elegant simplicity and beauty of Evolution to speak for itself, "Why Evolution is True" is arguably the best general-interest reference book on the scientific evidence for evolution currently in print.

I don't have any trouble believing in evolution - not even human evolution. I'm not sure why; maybe my world view is tolerant and reasonable; maybe I "evolved" (!) that way. Coyne's book is fantastically written in "human" rather than "scientist" fashion and introduces some items I hadn't known before. I'm well acquainted with the fact that human embryos go through stages where they very much resemble a fish, a reptile, other mammals, etc. But I was NOT familiar with the fact that humans also go through a state of "lanugo" - a fine, hairy coat of fur. It occurs in the human fetus at about 6 months after conception, exactly the point of development that it occurs in primates. However, ours disappears and theirs stays.Also, if we were created in God's image, he must not have been as omnipotent as we think he is. Otherwise, we would not have our twisty larynx nerve. It descends from the brain, parallel to the vagus nerve, then cuts over and goes UNDER the aorta and then back up to the larynx. Pretty stupid design I'd say. He also would have an appendix which appears to have no function, so why should he give it to us? I knew that but had never articulated it and looked it straight in the face.If you're interested at all in the science of evolution, rather than just the debate between evolutionists and creationist, read this. You'll come away with a much better understanding, and appreciation, of evolution.

The title gives this one away. He notes that yes, it’s a theory – but that doesn’t mean it’s simply some idea someone thought up. Instead, it’s some idea that someone thought up and has been confirmed by tons of evidence over the years. Heck, when Darwin came up with his theory, we had a very spotty fossil record (at best) – including pretty much none on humans. But since then we’ve found fossils, and they almost always seem to bare out what’s expected. For instance, scientists had an idea of a fish that looked like was pre-amphibian from 370 million years ago, and fossils of amphibians from 350 million years ago – so they looked in rocks from 360 million years ago and found a fish with a neck and fins that were nearly proto-limbs (and could breath some air) that was descended from the 370 million years ago fish. We have DNA evidence – and that backs it up. We have an idea of how evolution works: it’s when two strands of the same species get separated. For instance: Panama was created 3 million years ago, and on each side of it are 7 types of shrimp – 14 species in all – but their most similar species is the one ACROSS the isthmus. What’s more, on islands a little separated, you find species that are a little apart. The longer an island has been separated, the more distinct and different evolution is upon it. Creationsists just ignore this evidence. So you get marsupulas dominate in Australia, which has been on its own for a while. (Actually, it’s even stranger than that – the first fossils are in South America, but they crossed over during the supercontinent era – but the fossils show damn definite difference over time). Evolution is a theory – in the same way that gravity and relativity are theories (or atomic theory). He even notes that many creationists will accept microevolution, as we have clear evidence of that (most notably in animals we breed, like horses and dogs). He even notes how the eye evolved step-by-step. Scientists reckon it took 400,000 years. He’ll also go after some creationist claims. One popular creationist speaker mocks how the whale is related to the cow. Well guess what? Go step by step and it is. Some animals revert back to the water – and the hippo is a possible in-between stage. He also attacks intelligent design by noting how often its unintelligent. Turtles who bury their eggs sure would be better off with fins that could bury a lot better (especially since their exposed when burying eggs). A lot of our DNA is junk DNA that serves us no purpose anymore. The appendix – how is that intelligent for us? Lots of people died from that before modern medicine. For that matter, if is intelligent design – why have most species died out? How is that intelligent? Why do some cave fish still have eyeballs? Why do whales still have some bones that would’ve been hip-bones in their land days (and why do some still get an occasional limb coming out? – It’s dead DNA). Coyne notes that the fetus stage is full of evidence of evolution, including one spot where the fetus gets hairy. (Pediotrians know this, but they typically don’t realize the evolution connection). Creationists argue that if we can’t see a new species evolve over its lifetime, then evolution isn’t real. But this is fatuous – it’s like saying because we haven’t seen a star go through its lifecycle, then stars don’t evolve. Or that languages don’t evolve because we haven’t seen a new one emerge from scratch. We have evidence of evolution in humans. Lucy is ape from the neck-up, in the middle she’s a mixture, and from the waist down – almost a modern human. (This shows biped came before brain).

I follow the evolution / ID culture war pretty closely, but it occurred to me a while back that I had very little actual understanding of the science behind evolution. After reading Coyne’s book, I realize that I had more than I knew I did, but that I was missing a lot. Why Evolution is True demonstrates with strong clarity why evolution has proven itself to scientists as broadly and throughly as gravity. Unlike Miller’s Only a Theory, which focuses specifically on creationist arguments and why they’re bogus, Coyne explores evolution from the perspective of “how has this convinced us,” and he does so thoroughly. A few fun facts and good quotes: * Evolution depends on six concepts: “evolution, gradualism, speciation, common ancestry, natural selection, and nonselective mechanisms of evolutionary change.” Coyne explains each. * Whales descended from land animals. Their closest living relative is the hippo. They have hip and leg bones and occasionally one will be born with a leg. * The number of spots on the male peacock helps determine how sexy he is to the female peacock. One theory about this is that evolution to appreciate a certain color for unrelated reasons leads to sexual selection. Coyne writes “Suppose, for example, that members of a species had evolved a visual preference for red color because that preference helped them locate ripe fruits and berries. If a mutant male appeared with a patch of red on his breast, he might be preferred by females simply because of this preexisting preference.” (167) In other words, the females would select males because they look tasty. * The lineage of ape to human evolution is astonishingly well defined. The “hobbit” species, Homo floresiensis, an offshoot protected from worldwide species evolution by geographic barriers, lived as recently as 18,000 years ago. * The best argument against intelligent design is the bad design we find throughout complex life forms. By contrast, if we follow clues to explain development of one trait through adaptation from another, most of these bad designs make sense.One extended quote I really like. [Creationists argue:] that all the perceived evils of evolution come from two worldviews that are part of science: naturalism and materialism. Naturalism is the view that the only way to understand our universe is through the scientific method. Materialism is the idea that the only reality is the physical matter of the universe, and that everything else, including thoughts, will, and emotions, comes from physical laws acting on matter. The message of evolution, and all of science, is one of naturalistic materialism. Darwinism tells us that, like all species, human beings arose from the working of blind, purposeless forces over eons of time. As far as we can determine, the same forces that gave rise to ferns, mushrooms, lizards, and squirrels also produced us. Now, science cannot completely exclude the possibility of supernatural explanation. It is possible– though very unlikely—that our whole world is controlled by elves. But supernatural explanations like these are never needed: we manage to understand the natural world just fine using reason and materialism. Furthermore, supernatural explanations always mean the end of inquiry: that’s the way God wants it, end of story. Science, on the other hand, is never satisfied: our studies of the universe will continue until humans go extinct.

I couldn't shake that uncomfortable feeling, however, whenever the beauty of what was being described to me was constantly set alongside creationist arguments. I kept thinking, I'm already onboard! You don't need to proselytize me. It's cool! This book is trying to make a social statement, not just invite people to consider evolutionary theory on its own. I understand that in this way it is reactionary, cautioning against the ignorance of favouring "creationist" arguments in spite of the evidence. To be sure, it's pretty messed up that a textbook like On Pandas and People can disguise itself as a scientific resource while harbouring decidedly non-scientific ideas, be they true or false. As far as I can reason, religion and science are two separate domains.I guess what I mean to say is that if I could have written this book, as angry as I would be about religious politics and all the crap that blurs peoples' vision of the evidence, I wouldn't want to isolate such people as an audience. What he really questions is the way in which religious politics are encroaching on science, and how it may be holding us back from teaching amazing things to children. Evolution is enlightening. I think it can teach us to be kind to one another. It humbles us to smithereens. It grounds us right in this impossible moment, alive and heart beating. It lets us know that it's okay to feel whatever we feel - nothing is personal anymore! For me, reading books like this is a religious experience. I think there is more going on in religion that mere superstition and staunchness. And I am totally off track. Sorry about that.Also, I think it was cool that Coyne recognises his book is not going to change anything the way he wants it to. It's not a lack of evidence that prevents people from accepting evolutionary theory or at least considering it. He addresses this in the last chapter, and it's rather good.

In this deeply passionate account of evolution, scientist Jerry Coyne provides a wonderful and lucid argument for why a spate of mounting evidence, both confirmatory and predictive, lay claims for major tenets of evolution to be no longer tossed around as a "theory" but to be considered as "fact". Coyne begins with outlining the six fundamental tenets of evolutionary theory:(1) the idea of evolution - a species undergoes genetic change over time(2)gradualism - substantial evolutionary change takes many generations to produce(3) speciation - splitting occurs in evolving chains that creates multiple species(4) common ancestry - we can always look back in time and find descendants joining at their ancestors(5) the idea of natural selection - the nonrandom, differential reproduction of alleles (particular forms of mutated genes) from one generation to the next, and (6) processes other than natural selection that can cause evolutionary change, like genetic drift in populationsHe then provides evidence from multiple domains - the fossil record, biogeography, embryology, vestigial structures (a feature of a species that was an adaptation in its ancestors, but has lost its usefulness now or been co-opted for some unrelated use, like ostrich wings), atavisms (anomalies that look like the appearance of an ancestral trait, like some babies born with a tail), dead genes (the GLO pseudogene for Vitamin C production completely inactive in the human genome)and poor design (the recurrent laryngeal nerve, for example). All this evidence, argues Coyne, shows conclusively that organisms have evolved. Throughout this book, the author provides examples of predictions that scientists made about the likely course evolution would take, only to have evidence uncovered many years later that proved them right - notable examples include the discovery of the early land fish Tiktaalik and the discovery of marsupials in Antartica.The main takeaway here is that the main tenets of Darwinism are continuously being verified with scientific advances in related fields like genetics, molecular embryology, etc. Why then, Coyne asks, is there continued ambiguity about these tenets, though the very same folks accept the existence of electrons and black holes, although these notions are also removed from everyday experience? He makes the argument, rather convincingly, that this is because the "naturalism" of evolution gets erroneously extended to the domain of ethics and morality...that somehow the "selfishness" of Dawkins' The Selfish Gene provided a legitimacy to all selfish behaviors, which is misplaced. In the last chapter, Coyne makes his case of why it is important to separate the purposeless, materialistic way in which evolution operates from the notion that our lives have no purpose. Religious or secular thought, he argues, can assist in framing our purposes, meaning and morality.This book is a must-read. Most importantly, it reinvigorates in the reader the wonder of the universe and its myriad processes, and provides a brilliant and systematic account of how the scientific endeavor has helped us make empirical sense of it..
